editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE LONDON CUCKOLDS. A COMEDY; As it is Acted at The Duke's Theatre.
LONDON, Printed for Jos. Hindmarsh at the Sign of the Black-Bull near the Royal-Exchange in Cornhill, Anno Dom.1682.

div.head: PROLOGUE,
div.l: WEll; Now's your time, (my Masters of the Pit)
You that delight in Women, Wine and Wit.
All things this Winter jump for your delight,
In Mirth to wear the day, in Love the Night.
Now Fop may dine with Half-wit ev'ry noon,
And reade by Satyr, or his worse Lampoon.
Julian's so furnish'd by these scribling Sparks
That be pays off old Scores, and keeps two Clarks.
My Lady, with her eldest Daughter, brings to town
Michaelmas Rent, and vows she'll not go down
So long as her Sir John is worth a Crown.
The Theatres are up, and, to their cost,
Must strive, by Victory, to please you most:
Both he's and she's must stretch, in hopes to gain,
Like your New market Racers on the Strain.
Faith, give us Iockey-law without deceit,
Mark the mens inches well before their beat,
And let the Women have their Horse-mans weight.
For, Gallants, many of your Nymphs are come
At last from their respective Travels home;
Good News for you that love a Boosy Life,
And hate the Lectures of a carefull Wife.
That jointur'd Monsion never gives content
Like the convenient modish Tenement
That's held by moderate Lease or yearly Rent.
But if with me Misses would counsel joyn,
We'd make the Tenant pay a swingeing Fine.
If Celia thoughtless in her Alcove sits,
With Indian Tables pleas'd and Cabinets,
Soon for her Fault, or else some Trick of State,
She proves the Turn of her uncertain Fate.
Then waking (like the Tinker in the Play)
She finds the golden Vision fled away.
But if you drain your Keeper till be's poor,
And have the wit to lay it up in store;
He marries you in hopes to mend his life,
And what he lost by th'Mistress, gains in th'Wife.

list.head: Actors Names.
list.label: Wiseacre, Doodle, Two Aldermen of London,
Mr. Townly, A Gentleman of the times, careless of Women, but fortunate,
Mr. Ramble, A great Designer on Ladies, but unsuccessfull in his Intrigues,
Mr. Loveday, A young Merchant, one that had formerly been a Lover of Eugenia,
Eugenia, Wife to Dashwell, a Pretender to Wit,
Arabella, Wife to Doodle, a Hypocrite,
Peggy, Bride to Wiseacre, an Innocent, and Country-bred,
Aunt, Governess to Peggy,
Engine, Woman to Arabella,
Iane, Eugenia's Maid,
Roger, Tom, Two Footmen to Ramble and Townly.
A Linkboy, Two Chimny-sweepers, Watchmen.

div.head: Act I. Scene I.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: WELL, Mr. Alderman Doodle, you promise to go along with me.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Yes, I will dispence with business, since 'tis on this occasion; who else goes?

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Onely Mr. Dashwell, our City Attorney, your neighbor, who draws the writings for the Jointure.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: You'll be going as soon as Change is done?

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Yes. Well, you shall see the most simple innocent thing of a wife, I so hugg my self with the thoughts of her.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: What! Is she silly say you?

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: A meer infant in her Intellects: But for her bigness You'd take her for a baby.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: How old is she?

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: But fourteen.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: An Infant to you indeed: why, you are near fifty.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Marry a fool and a child too!

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Ay, to choose.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: But a discreet woman of thirty had been more sutable for you.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: But my intention is to marry a woman that will be young when I am old.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Doubtless an old man will be very agreeable to a young woman.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p:
I have consider'd that point too, and am convinc'd that an old man can never love an old woman, that's for certain. Age is a sure decayer and
renders men backward in their duty, therefore I marry a woman so young, that she may be a temptation to me when I am old. You may talk of Amber-cawdles, Chocolate, and Jelly-broths, but they are nothing comparable to youth and beauty, a young woman is the onely provocative for old age, I say.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Oh, is that your drist?

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Brother Alderman, I have liv'd long a Batchelor, I begin late, and so would lengthen out my satisfaction as far as I can.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: I perceive that's as to her youth: but why do you marry one so silly? where's the satisfaction of that?

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: There you are short of comprehension agen: why, a young wife that has wit would play the Devil with an old Husband. Why, you see a young one can hardly keep 'em from kicking backward in this age.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Some such there are at the other end of the Town: but we have few of them here in the City.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: That I might be sure not to be troubled with a witty, wife, I made choice of a Girle of four years of age, one that had no signs of a pregnant wit, her father and mother were none of the wisest; they dying, left this child to the care of her Aunt, a good honest decay'd Gentlewoman, but a little soft too; her portion they recommended to my hands, to be improv'd for her use; I plac'd the Aunt and child in the Countrey, at a lone house, instructed her to breed her up in all honesty and simplicity immaginable; never to let her play amongst Boyes or Girles, or have any conversation with any body but her self, and now being bred to my own humour, and moulded to my turn, I am going to reap the fruits of my long care and trouble; for this is she I design for my wife.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: What need you to bestow all this pains to make a fool? were there not fools enough of Heavens making?

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Yes, but those fools, if not meer Idiots and Drivelers, grow wiser by experience, and by that time they come to twenty years of age are quite other things; this forward age ripens them apace; Girles now at sixteen are as knowing as Matrons were formerly at sixty, I tell you in these days they understand Aristotle's Problems at twelve years of age.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: 'Tis true indeed, nothing in the nature of man or woman is a secret to them. I'll be sworn, Mr. Alderman, the other day I catcht two young wenches, the eldest not above twelve, reading the beastly, bawdy translated book called the Schoole of Women. O to say the truth 'tis a very forward knowing age.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Why brother, I hear at that damn'd lewd other end of the Town there is a Bawd in a bib and apron not ten years old.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: They are no sooner out of the nurses arms, but they run into a man's.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: To secure my self against all this, I have been at the charge to breed up a fool, and will now marry her so young that I may make a fool of her all her life long, and I will keep her and order her so, as she shall never grow wiser.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: But the chief end of a wife, is to be a comfort and a companion to a man, and what satisfaction can a husband have to converse with one so simple that she can scarce tell her right hand from her left?

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Ignorance is the mother of devotion, I can therefore make her doe what I will, whate'r I shall say she will believe, and whate'r I will have her doe, she will think it her duty, and obey for fear.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Wou'd you have your wife a slave?

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: O much rather than be a slave to a wife: A witty wife is the greatest plague upon earth, she will have so many tricks and inventions to deceive a man, and cloak her villany so cunningly, a husband must always be upon the spy, watch when he should sleep, seem to sleep when he should be awake, to secure his honour against her inventions; of all which cares and troubles, he is freed that has married a wife who has not wit enough to offend.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: If my wife was a fool, I should always suspect her a whore, for 'tis want of wit that makes 'em believe the flatteries of men; she that has sense will discern their traps and snares and avoid 'em: I tell you, Mr. Alderman, a woman without sense, is like a castle without souldiers, to be taken at every assault.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: But I say still, wit is a dangerous weapon in a woman, and simplicity is her best guard.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: I tell you, brother Wiseacres, you are in the wrong.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: I tell you, brother Doodle, I am in the right.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: A woman with wit will be cunning enough for men.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Ay, and too cunning for her husband: you have a witty wife, much good may doe you with her.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: And much good may doe you with your fool.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Better be a fool than a wanton.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Better be a wanton than both.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Your positiveness provokes me.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: And your want of reason provokes me.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: I hope you will allow that a witty wife may be a slut.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: But a foolish wife will certainly be one.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: What has rais'd this heat betwixt you?

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: O Mr. Dashwell, in good time, you shall be judge now, we are in dispute here, whether 'tis best for a man to have a wife with wit, or one that's a fool; which is safest for a husband's reputation, to have a little, laughing, gigling, highty, tighty, pratling, tatling gossipping wife, such a one as he has married?

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p:
Or a silly simple, peaking, sneaking bashfull, awkard, ill-bred, Countrey girle, that goes with her toes in, and can't say boah to a Goose, who can onely answer, I forsooth and no forsooth, and stands in aw of her Chambermaid;
such a one as my brother Alderman Wiseacres here, has taken pains to rear for his own proper use.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Just such a silly, simple, bashfull thing I am for, I desire my wife should have neither wit nor money but what is in my keeping, what need my wife have wit to make her loud, talkative and impertinent, when I have enough for her and my self too?

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: I am for the contrary, now Mr. Dashwell, which of us two do you think is in the right?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: In the right?

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Ay.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Why, I think you both in the wrong.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Both in the wrong!

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: How can that be?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Each wou'd be safe in a wife, as to his reputation, wou'd you not?

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Then let me tell you for both your comforts, a wife that has wit will out-wit her husband, and she that has no wit will be out witted by others beside her husband, and so 'tis an equal lay, which makes the husband a Cuckold first or oftnest.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: You are a married man, Mr. Dashwell, what course have you taken?

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Ay, is yours wise or foolish? tell us that.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Look you, the security lies not in the foolish wife, or in the witty wife, but in the godly wife, one that prays and goes often to Church, mind you me, the religious godly wife, and such a one have I.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: O, the godly wife.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Meer hypocrites all, a godly woman! I wou'd not have my wife a Church zealot. How many Cuckolds must there needs be in a Parish when the bell tolls out our wives twice a day to assignations?

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Nor do I like my wife should be catechised by a smooth fac'd Reader, or a Lecturer, I don't know what doctrine he may put into her.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: I had rather my wife shou'd have company and play at crosspurposes, and questions and commands at home, than go to church to play at hide and seek in a pew; for my part, I am scandalized, there are many pews in the Church. I don't know but—well, I don't like it, and so much good may doe you with your good godly wife.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Well, the world has never been of one mind since there was above one man in't, and ne'r will be again so long as there are two, so let there be an end of this discourse, and to our business, where shall I bring the writings to you, that you, that you may reade'em before we go?

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: I'll be, in half an hour, at Garraway's Coffee house.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I'll go and acquaint my wife I'm going out of Town, and meet you there.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p:
Mr. Alderman, I believe you percieve by my principles, that I intend my wife shall be no Gossiper, nor wife, of the times to visit and be visited, even by her own sex, therefore you need not acquaint your wife
with any thing of my marriage, that she may not take it ill that I make her no invitation to my wife; I will marry her to morrow morning in private, and she shall live retir'd and private, as she has been bred.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: As you please for that.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: You'll meet us anon upon Change?

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: I'll but tell 'em within I'm going out of Town, about business, and follow you.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: We'll expect.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: This is an od humour, I can't but laugh to think what sport the women will make with him, when they hear on't, my wife will make him mad.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Ha ha ha ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Engine.
sp.p: Ha ha ha ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Thou art very merry, wife, this morning.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Prithee what dost laugh at?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Lord, husband! that your wife was but a fool; what a fine time wou'd you have on't?

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: What, you over-heard our discourse?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: We have been listning at the door this half hour.

sp.speaker: Engine.
sp.p: Marry there's a fine project; marry a fool! sure he intends to keep her altogether in hanging sleeves.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: He had a fling at me in his discourse, but I'll be reveng'd if ever I can come to speak to his filly wife; I'll reade her a Chapter of Wisdome shall clear her understanding.

sp.speaker: Engine.
sp.p: I am deceiv'd if this Town do not teach her wit.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: I am affraid, he won't reap as he sowes; this is not an age for the multiplication of fools, in the female sex.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: He has taken great pains to make her one.

sp.speaker: Engine.
sp.p: How far off is this pattern of innocence?

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: But few miles from London, he marries her to morrow morning, and brings her home.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: And you, husband, are to goe upon this piece of gallantry, to fetch the Lady?

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: He desir'd, and I have promis'd.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Are we to expect you home at dinner?

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: No, we shall dine together about Change, there take Coach. Well, wife, you shall see me again to morrow, there's a kiss to remember me till my return. Adieu.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p:
Adieu, husband. A kiss! slender diet to live upon till to morrow this time: I have a months mind to greater dainties, to feast in his absence upon lustier fare than a dull City husband, as insipid and ill relisht as a
Guild hall-dish on a Lord Mayor's day. Now, Engine, if I durst pursue my inclinations with the man you have so often heard me speak of.

sp.speaker: Engine.
sp.p: A little variety, Madam, wou'd be pleasant; always to feed upon Alderman's flesh is enough to cloy your stomach.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: He's so sparing on't it can never surfeit me.

sp.speaker: Engine.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, they that have spare dyet at home may the better be allow'd to look abroad. Troth, Madam, ne'r lose your longing.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: But how, Engine, what contrivance to let him know it? to write to him wou'd not doe so well.

sp.speaker: Engine.
sp.p: Troth doe, Madam, write to him, a little Letter of rallery, that may look like a frolick as it were between Jest and Earnest.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Writing wou'd show too great a forwardness.

sp.speaker: Engine.
sp.p: No matter; if a right Cavalier, he will make the more haste to relieve a Lady in distress.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: No, thou shalt go to him, thou hast a pretty good way of speaking; I'll give thee some general hints and leave it to thy management.

sp.speaker: Engine.
sp.p: I'll doe my part, I'll warrant you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Come, wee'll consider on't.

sp.speaker: Engine.
sp.p: There needs but little consideration in this case, if you like the Gentleman, I'll secure you, the Gentleman shall like you.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Have a care how you turn Insurer, Love is a doubtfull voyage.

sp.speaker: Engine.
sp.p: Yes, if the venture be in a leaky rotten bottome, or such a slugg as your husband.—But in such a well built ship, so finely rig'd as that you speak of, you run no risk at all, I'll insure you for two in the hundred.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Well then, thou shalt go see of what burthen my Lover is, and if he has stoage-room left for a heart, contract for mine; but tell him, what foul weather soever happens he shall preserve mine, though he throw all the rest over-board.

sp.speaker: Engine.
sp.p: That's not to be fear'd in such a tall stout ship, so rig'd and man'd, methinks I have him in ken already, bearing up briskly to you, spreading all sailes for haste, to clap you on board.— Methinks I see him lye cross your Haser already.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Come, wench, thy tongue runs, and we lose time.

sp.speaker: Engine.
sp.p: I'll regain it in my expedition.

div.stage: Enter Ramble and Townly, in Morning-gowns.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Prethee, Ned Ramble, what makes thee so early a riser after so late a debauch as we made last night?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Business, Frank.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Business! what business can a Gentleman have to make him rise at ten, that went drunk to bed, at four in the morning?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: I am pursuing an intreague, a new Mistress, Frank.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p:
An intreague! thou art alwaies upon intreagues; I never knew any of your intreagues come to any thing; there's no fellow in Town has
been so bawk'd as thou hast, in all thy adventures; you see I never make it my business to look after women, and yet they fall in my way, and I am successfull, whereas thou art always coursing 'em about, and when you are at the very scut of 'em, thou losest 'em.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: The truth is, I have been unfortunate hitherto, I always meet with occasions, but never bring 'em to perfection; yet it is not my fault neither, for either my mistress jilts me, fortune jilts me, or the Devil prevents me, I can never bring it to a home-push; when I think I have overcome all difficulties and am as sure of a woman as a Hawk is of the prey he swoops at, Fortune turns her wheel, a whirlewind blows my Mistress into Asia and I am tost into America.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Therefore prethee leave hunting, that difficult game, and learn of me to divert thy self with a bottle, leave enquiring where there's a pretty woman, and ask where the best wine is, take women as I do, when they come in thy way by accident; you will never be successfull so long as you make it your business; Love like riches comes more by fortune than industry.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Perseverance will overcome destiny; I shall have good luck in the end.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Never till you make drinking your chief diversion, O Ned, wine gives a certain elevation of spirit, quickens and enlivens the fancy to that degree, that a man half bowsy shall advance farther with a woman in one encounter, than a sober fellow as thou art in ten, there's a certain boldness and alacrity wanting which lets a womans fancy sink and grow lukewarm when she was just boyling o'r.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: If I shou'd keep company but one week with thee, Franck Townly, and drink as we did yesterday, I shou'd be fit neither for the company of women nor men, I am so squeamish and maukish to day.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Custome will overcome that; come lets goe and find out some honest fellows, and dine together, and drink away thy complaints.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: I'll have no more on't, I thank you, this month.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: If I had thought this, I would have lain at my own Lodgings last night; I consented to lie with you, thinking to have been sure of you all this day, but since you will be stragling out of my clutches, cross sates and thy own fortune pursue thee.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Every one in their own element; let me find pretty women, and take you the good wine, I envy you not.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: As soon as e'r my business in Lumbard-street is done, I'll abandon this sober end of the Town, Where a man can't reel into a Tavern, after eleven a clock, for sawcy Constables and watchmen, that will wait on a man home against his will.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I find a great conveniency in a lodging here, I can be master of my own will▪ and free from all importunate Solicitors, that dun a man more to go to the Tavern than a Tradesman does for money.

sp.speaker: Roger,
sp.p: A Porter, Sir, brought you this Letter.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: A Womans Hand—augh!

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: A Bait to draw you into your old Snare; the Consequence will be unlucky.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: No, I fear it not: Where is the Porter?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: He told me it requir'd no Answer.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Lay my Cloaths ready that I may dress me.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: What is this hastly Business?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: A bold Challenger, and I'll not fail to meet the fair Inviter.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Pray tell me; is this a new Amour?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: A new one! I neither know her Name, nor where she Lives.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: No better acquainted, and yet send you a Summons?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: But we have converst together sometime; I have bow'd to her, kist my Hand to her, look'd Amorously on her, stood by her and Sight, Whisper'd her cross the Pew and stole Notes into her hand.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: This is a Church Lady then, some old Countess, or Rich Widdow, with whom thou dost intend to drudg out a fortune, and with dry slavish Letchery raise thy self to the equipage of a Stalion.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Have better thoughts of your Friend; No, she is neither Old nor Ugly, nor one whom Fortune has yet so much blest to put into the state of Widdowhood; she is a Wife, young, plump, pretty, and blooming as the Spring.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: What is her Husband?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: A Blockheaded City Attorney; a Trudging, Drudging, Cormuging, Petitioning Citizen, that with a little Law and much Knavery has got a great Estate.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: A Petitioner! Cuckold the Rogue for that very reason.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: By the Inducement of her Parents she Married him against her inclinations, and now nauseating her Husband's bed, rises every Morning by Five or Six with a pretence to hear Lectures and Sermons, and loathing his Company at home, pretends all day to be at Prayers, that she may be alone in her Chamber.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: And that Billet is from her?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: From her Maid, from whom with a Bribe I learnt all this. You shall hear the Contents.

body.p: My Master is going out of Town, and I have workt upon my Mistres's Inclinations to admit you this night: Be at your Lodgings in the Evening, and expect me to come and be your Guide to the Happiness you wish for.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: 'Tis strange a man shoud find a Mistress at Church that never goes to one.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: 'Tis true, till of late, I had never been at Church since my Father's Funeral, and I had not gone then, but to Conduct him as forward on his way as I coud, that he might not return to take the Estate again I got by his Death: Nor had I been near a Church since, but for a suddain shower of Rain that drove me into a Church-porch for shelter, and whilst I was standing there, came by this Miracle of a Woman and wrought my Conversion.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: But as often as you have been there, you never said your Prayers?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Only the Love Litany, and some amorous Ejaculations, as thou Dear Creature, Charming Excellence, Ravishing Beauty, Heavenly Woman, and such flights as these; I durst not pray against Temptation least Heaven shoud have taken me at my word, and have spoil'd my Intreague.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Spoke like a Cavalier, e'gad! if thy inclinations did but lye a little more to the Bottle, thou woudst be an admirable honest Fellow.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Sir, here's a Gentlewoman desires to speak with you in private.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Is she a Lady?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: An ingenious Attendant I believe.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Bring her up. Townly, let me beg your pardon, and desire you to step into the next room.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Another Love Ambassadress; I'll withdraw till you give her audience.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: There's my Master.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: A good morrow to you, Mistress:

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: The like to you, Sir; My wish will be successfull since I bring you such good news.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Pray come nearer; what is it I pray, and from whom?

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: From a fair Lady, Sir. I hope we are private?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Fear not; pray go on.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Perhaps you will wonder, Sir, and think me Confident, when I shall tell you?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Nothing can make me think amiss of one that has such auspicious signs in her countenance.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: You are pleas'd to flatter me; but pray wonder not, Sir, at my forwardness, since it is to do so worthy a person service, and a Gentleman of such extraordinary merits as your self.—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Now you Compliment me, pray let me hear my Good-morrow from those pretty Lips.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p:
I protest, I blush at my undertaking. But since I am no waies
concern'd on my own account, I can with better courage proceed.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Pray do; you have rais'd me to a wonderfull expectation.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: And yet when you have consider'd how accomplish'd a person you are, and how worthily you attract the eyes of Ladies, you think it then no wonder at all that a Lady of as great wit and beauty as any the City affords, thinks you the most admirable person of your whole Sex. One that talks of you with so much delight and fervency, that I thought it injustice, even to you, as well as injurious to her, if I should not acquaint you.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Be free with me—Pray who is this Lady whose thoughts are so favourable to me?

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: A rich Alderman's young Wife, one that has been married above Six months. One so far from the City breeding—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: She speaks so prettily in your praise, and has the tenderest sentiments in her thoughts for you.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: And o'r whom you have such an Ascendancy that coud she be assur'd, you were one woud be secret, and with whom her reputation might be safe—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: She could Love me; is it so?

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: It is indeed. And saies after such an assurance, it were no longer in her power to refuse you any favour coud be expected from a Woman.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Thou pourest harmony in my ears; the sweet sound strikes upon my Heart-strings and makes it rebound with joy. Take this Gold to encourage thee; Say, where is this obliging Beauty, when shall I see her?

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Her Husband is this day gone out of Town, now is a convenient time to make your addresses.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Conduct me to her, and let me fall before her with humble adoration.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Not till night, that darkness may secure her reputation from the censure of prying Neighbours, Visitants of your Garb and noble Meen draw all eyes; be therefore prudent, and approach with caution and circumspection as Misers do to the hoard of Wealth they are afraid to lose.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: I'll think her a Mine of Gold, myself the Indian that has discover'd it, and imagine all the Citizens Spaniards that would rob me of't, so secretly I will approach—

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Such prudence will secure a lasting Joy, and long may you reap the spoils of Love and Beauty.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: But where, where my little Ang •• Intelligencer, where is this blessing to be found? Which way shall I direct my uncertain steps? or by what title is she distinguish'd from other women, for yet I know her but by these excellencies, the fairest and the kindest of her Sex?

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p:
These Tablets I took from her, in those you will find her name with Characters that will direct you to this beauty; but confine your censures
to just bounds, and interpret not that my officiousness proceeds from any command of hers.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Not in the least.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: 'Tis true, I know the secrets of her heart—and since I was sure it would not be displeasing to her, and you were a party so highly deserving, I took the Liberty without her knowledge to do you both this piece of service.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: I can never think amiss of her Love nor your Service, but must bless the means that conducts me to my happiness. Now pray favour me with some further knowledge of your Self, least wanting opportunity to oblige, I should appear ungratefull.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: My name is Engine, my inclinations to this fair person, lead me to be a Domestick in her family, and she is pleas'd to make me her Confident.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: I rejoice you are so nearly concern'd: Let my interest still be your care; and if such small acknowledgments as these can quit my Score, I hope not to dye your Debtor.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Your merits bind me beyond your gift.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Dear Mistress Engine, Yours?

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Your Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Who's there, wait down. Now for her Name and place of habitation,—where!— Looks in the book. Oh here—Mrs. Arabella Wife to Alderman—

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Ned, you must pardon my Curiosity, I coud not but listen, I heard all the business; if ever thou prove successfull in an Intreague, it will be this.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: That two appointments shoud happen so at the same time, one to prevent the other.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: If you are doubtfull which to choose, e'n throw up Cross or Pile.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: No, I resolve to attempt the other first, because I know the person, I am sure she pleases me; what perfections this has, are yet unknown to me, therefore with more ease neglected.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Who is this Woman, what's her name?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Excuse me there; It is not like a Gallant man to reveal a kind Lady's name: That and her place of habitation are here set down in fair Characters. Thus was the happy secret entrusted to me.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Haw! let me but observe the outside.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Look no longer, 'tis not of your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Not know it, 'twas mine once.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: No, no thou art deceiv'd: Thine!

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Mine, I know it by the Clasps: pray look on the inside of the Cover, and see if there be not a Cupid drawn with a Red-lead Pen?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: 'Gad, Franck thou hast ghest right, here is.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: 'Tis then the same; the Woman I gave it to, is the person of all the World I most fancy.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Was she very handsome?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: I know not the charms of her Face, 'tis her Wit I admire.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Has it been then a night Intreague and carried on in the dark?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: No, I have seen her often in a Vizard at Playes, she has a delicate shape, and a pretty, pretty hand; she once show'd me that for a Sample, and if her skin all over be like that, Snow was never whiter, nor Alabaster half so sleek and Polished.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Yet should her face not be answerable.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Oh, she has a Tongue would charm a man, she is all Air, Mirth and Wit,—but I had her own Word for't that her face was no disparagement to her body.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: But for all that, this may be some common Town Lady.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: No, no she had Rings and Jewels too valuable to be one of those, she was Roguish but not Impudent, Witty but not Rampant; without doubt she has a husband that is proud of her, and takes delight to hear her talk, for I observ'd kind of City Elder always sit a little distant from her, who listen'd to her rallery with the Sparks, and seem'd pleas'd in his countenance when she was smart in her Repartees upon the little Cockerills of the Pit that came flirting at her with their sparring blows.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: And sitting at distance, might be on purpose to give her opportunity, to exercise her tallent.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Questionless 'twas so, for with this man she always went out when the Play was done.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: But how came she by your Tablets?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: I was humming a new Song one day in the Pit, and she ask'd me if I could give it her. I had it written down there, I presented the book to her, but could hardly force it on her, because she thought it of some value.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: But took it at last?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Yes, upon condition I would accept the book back agen the next time we met in the Pit.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: I am glad to hear her Character, and now am more dissatisfi'd that one Intreague should cross the other.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Since it so falls out, give me the directions, and I will go in your place.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Thank you for that—

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: You can secure but one to your self,—you'll certainly lose her you disappoint.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: No, no, I'll keep two strings to my Bow, if any accident cross one design, I have the other Lady in reserve; and now I think my self secure above the malice of Fortune, and laught at all her former spight.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p:
I know thou art positive, ill natur'd and hard-hearted, and wouldst not part with one hadst thou twenty. But for punishment I wish thee the same curse I do to Misers that hoard up Gold, and woud not part
with any to save a man from starving:—which is, that you may be rob'd of all, and after hang thy self with grief for the loss.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Alas, Frank Townly, I thought you could not be in love with any thing but a bottle, what, would you leave all your merry Friends for a woman, they'd take it unkindly.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Evil Fates are boading o'r thy head, and so, Churle, Farewell.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Spight of thy Prophecy, meet me to morrow morning, and I'll tell thee such pleasant stories of this nights joys, thou shalt for ever be converted from wine to women.
sp.l: Women are Miracles the Gods have given,
That by their brightness we may ghess at Heaven.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: MAdam, Mr. Ramble will be here presently.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Well, Iane, though I love Mr. Ramble, yet are not my inclinations so much in fault as your counsells, for had not you perswaded me, I should never have consented to his coming to night in my husband's absence.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: I vow to you, Madam, it grieved me to see how the poor Gentleman sigh'd and lookt pale, and watch'd all opportunities to see you, and how constantly he came to Church, where, but for your sake, I dare swear, he would as soon have been hang'd as come, and then what complaints did he make of your reservedness when I knew it was against your conscience to deny him, for I was sure you lov'd him.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I did so, Iane, ah! were my husband but such a man, how happy a creature should I be? but I was forced to marry him to please my parents.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: 'Tis then your turn to please your self now with a Gallant, to supply the defects of a husband; when a man will press a woman to marry against her inclinations, he lays the foundation himself of being a Cuckold after: Troth Madam, think no more of your husband, but of your Gallant, the man you love, who is this night come to your embraces, I'll warrant you you'll not repent your self to morrow morning.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: If unexpectedly my husband should return—

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: No fear of that.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Hark, some body knocks, run to the door.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Loveday, meanly habited, in black.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Who would you speak with, Sir?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Is Mr. Dashwell within?

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: He is out of Town, and returns not till to morrow.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Is his Lady at home?

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Yes—there she is.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Your business, Sir.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I have Letters to him, from his brother at Hamburgh, the Merchant, in which he recommends me to him for a servant, or at least a short entertainment in his family, till I have dispatched some business he is pleased to imploy me in.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Iane, this is unlucky, what shall we doe? his being in the house will put a restraint on our freedome to night.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: No, Madam, I'll dispatch him to bed, do but you give order, and then let me alone.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: My husband will be in Town to morrow, and then he will resolve you if he wants a servant, my house is not well provided of beds at present, you must be content with a lodging in the Garret; Iane, take care to see him lodged, I am sleepy and will go to my chamber, Iane, make haste, for I am not very well.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Come, Sir, you have rid a long journey to day, and may be weary, I'II Show you to your chamber, there's a bed ready made.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I came but from Canterbury to day.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Because my Lady's not well, let me beg you to be content with a sack posset to night, which as soon as she's in bed, shall be brought up to you, to morrow we'll make you amends as soon as you please.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: That shall suffice; but let me now request a glass of beer.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, sit down, you shall have that presently.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: How fair Engenia look'd, her beauty's still fresh and blooming, with how much joy in this short interview have I beheld those eyes, whose wounds I have born so long, and felt their influence at so great a distance? I wish she had not been indispos'd.—Her husband out of Town and she alone.—This had been a time.—hah, what room's that, what's there, a Cloath laid, Knives, Napkins, Oranges and bread.—Late as it is here will be a supper, all this preparation cannot be for to morrow, some body is to come in the Husbands absence, Eugenia pretends to be gone to bed, her indisposition is feign'd, my company was unseasonable, to lodge me in the Garret was policy, but I'll venture to observe passages.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Sir, here's a glass of Drink.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I thank you, I was very dry.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Now, Sir, if you please, I will light you to your chamber.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Withall my heart, for I am very weary; 'tis so, they relish not my company, and are for posting me supperless to bed, onely to remove me out of the way.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Come, Sir, now come in here.—Well, Mr. Ramble, you see what influence, you Gentlemen have over us weak women.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Oh my dear Life, my Joy, let me not answer thee but in this Language.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I ne'r thought I should condescend to admit you to my house in my husbands absence thus, what will you think of me?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: I'll think thee the kindest, lovingst, the dearest and the best of thy whole sex; come, let us reserve our thoughts till anon, till I have thee in bed in my arms, where darkness will privilege thee to tell thy thoughts without a blush freely, as I could now, were it not for loss of time, and that I should lose so many sweet kisses the while.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Use your conquest with discretion, and put me not to my blushes, I confess I can deny you nothing, and 'tis too late now to retreat.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Be not faint hearted nor ashamed, now Fortune has blessed us with the opportunity;—now let us be all rapture, all fire, kiss, hug and embrace, and never have done.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Hark.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Madam, Supper is upon the Table.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Draw the Table in here, this room is more private.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Come, Madam, let us prepare our selves with meat and wine, yet make but a hasty meal of it that we may the sooner come to that more delicious Banquet, the feast that Love has prepar'd for us, that feast of Soul and Senses, and of all at once.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Have a care of feeding to heartily on Love, 'tis a surfeiting dyet, with which your Sex is soon cloy'd, and that is the reason you men seek variety so much.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Fear not that now, for thou art a dish of all varieties, like a spanish Olio that contains the best of every thing; all the beauties of thy whole Sex, all their charms are here in this one composition.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Madam, the meat will be cold.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Come, Sir, now you have said grace, sit down.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: Mrs. Iane, oblige me with a glass of Wine.
Madam, this to your good Health:
Fill the glass, and bring't to me agen.
sp.stage: [She fills it, and he puts Gold into't.
sp.p: I drank your Lady's health, Mrs Iane, you must pledge it; there are some ingredients to make the wine relish.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Iane, have a care what you doe, Mr. Ramble is corrupting you to let him into my chamber after I am in bed anon.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: O sweet remembrance, wisht for hour!

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: But be sure, Iane, you don't let him have the Key.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: No, Madam, I'll be sure to put that in my pocket, when you are both lock'd in.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Thank you, Mrs. Iane.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I see you have corrupted my servant already: Fie upon you.—Come, Sir, will you carve, or shall I.—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: You if you please, Madam, I am so ecstasy'd with the thoughts of approaching bliss.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Iane, run to the door, and see who knocks.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Who can it be thus late?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Pray Heaven it be not my Husband.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: No no, Fortune will not be such an enemy to Love.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Hark agen.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Heavens, Madam, 'tis my Master.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Iane, what shall we doe.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Cursed spite, where shall I hide?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Heavens, how he knocks.—

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Go into the Closet, Sir, there, there.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Thrust in Table and all, the Wine too: Table and all is put into the Closet. So, if it be my Husband, tell him I am at my prayers and would not be disturb'd:—get him to go up to bed.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Yes, Madam,—He'll beat down the door.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Stay, where is my Prayer-book.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: In the Window, Madam.

div.stage: Eugenia settles her self to reade upon the Couch.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Is my Wife in the Parlor? we'll go in to her.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: She is at her Prayers and would not be disturb'd.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Let her pray anon,—I have brought Mr. Alderman Doodle to see her.—Wife, come prethee, Wife, leave off praying, thou art always a praying, lay by thy Book.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Oh me, Husband, are you come home, indeed I did not expect you to night. Mr. Alderman, your humble servant.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Your servant, good Mrs. Dashwell.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I hope your Wife's well.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: I left her well in the morning; she's not at her prayers, I'll warrant you, e'n a little of that serves her.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Truly I think I cannot spend my time better.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Well, wife, prithee what hast thou for our supper, we are very hungry, the fresh air has got us a stomach?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Truly, husband, not expecting you home, I provided nothing, we made shift with what was left at dinner, there is nothing at all in the house.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Well neighbour, now I have seen you home, I'll leave you.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Nay nay, stay and drink a glass of Wine.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: This is a fit time for me to appear—I have observ'd all, and will startle'em.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Who is this?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: O my dear, I had forgot to tell you, this young man comes from your Brother at Hambrough with recommendations to you.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Here's a Letter from him, Sir, I was just going to bed, but when I heard you come, I slip'd on my cloaths and made bold to trouble you to night to know your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Reach me the Candle, Iane, and fill some wine.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: How did it happen pray, that you all return'd to night?

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: My brother Alderman and I heard of a business upon Change to day in which we are both concern'd, that will require our presence there to morrow, therefore he resolv'd to bring his Bride to Town to night and be Married early in the morning.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Is she come then?

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: We left her and her Aunt at the Coach, he is come before to his house to provide for their reception.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: The Marriage I suppose will be private?—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Yes, there will be only the Aunt, your husband, and my self, if I can be there. Mr. Wiseacres has the oddest humours, he will have her call him Uncle.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: She is very young I hear, and therefore—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: My Brother gives you a very good General Character, he speaks much of your fidelity and sober carriage, but names not any particular imployment that you are fit for; pray what are you capable of?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I have bin bred a Scholar, taken some degrees at the University— I can write and account well.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Very good—I know not whether I shall have occasion of you as a Clerk under me for Law business, or whether I should recommend you to some friend amongst the Merchants to be imploy'd in his Counting-house —I'll consider against to morrow; for my Brother's sake I'll see to get you some imployment?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p:
I humbly thank you, Sir. One thing more let me tell you of my
abilities: Whilst I was a Scholar at Oxford, I studied a very mysterious Art, and spent much time in the contemplation of Magick, which the Vulgar call the Black-Art; for this I was expell'd the University. I can perform something wonderfull, yet without danger, and to morrow or any time when you and your Lady are at leasure, I will show something of my skill for your diversion.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Oh goodness Husband! I would not see Conjuring for all the World, it is a naughty wicked thing; I shant sleep to night for thinking there is one in the house that knows the Black-Art.—Iane, besure you lay my Prayer-book under my Pillow to night.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Fear not Lady, you shall have no hurt from me—it is very usefull —sometimes—I can by my Art discover private enemies, reveal Robberies, help right Owners to goods stolen or lost; to Ships becalm'd, procure a wind shall bring'em to the Port desir'd—and the like.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: I begg your pardon, I believe nothing of all this.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I would you cou'd help us to a good Supper to night, for I am damnable hungry.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Ay, and not stay the dressing of't—

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: That Sir,—I'll do't with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Canst thou—?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: In a trice, the easiest thing of a hundred.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Prithee do then.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: O Lord husband! what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Nay nay, ne'r fright your self, you'll see no such thing.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I'll warrant you a supper, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Sayst thou so. But let it be hot.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Hot, Ay, Sir—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: It must needs be hot if it comes from the Devil.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I hope he's not in earnest.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Fear not, Madam, but sit you down; and you, Sir, by your Lady, and you on the other hand—sweet heart, stand you behind your Lady's chair.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: What does this fellow mean?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: For heavens sake, husband, let me begon.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: No no, sit down; come begin.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Have patience, you shall see nothing to fright you. Silence I pray. Mephorbus, Mephorbus, Mephorbus: Thrice I have thee invoked my Familiar— be thou assistant straight to my desires, supply what e'r a hungry appetite requires. By all the powers of the Zodiack, Aries, Taurus, Gemini, Cancer, Leo, Virgo, Libra, Scorpio, Sagittarius, Capricorn, Aquarius, Pisces. Assist ye seven Planets to, Mars, Sol, Venus, Mercury, Luna, Dragons Head and Dragons Tayl. Shed your auspicious influences, and to my Charm give efficacious strength.

sp.speaker: Ian.
sp.p: Oh the Devil is coming, I smell Brimstone already.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Peace you Baggage, you have sup'd.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: I begin to sweat for't—would I were under the Table, that the Devil mayn't see me if he comes.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Tacete—

div.stage: After the charms stands with his head as listning to an invisible—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: That's hold your peace.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Arlom Gascodin Adelphon, Eu • , Eusticon Olam Amemnos. Thanks Mephorbus. Now, Sir, you may prepare to fall to.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Why, I see no meat—the Devil has fail'd you—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: I thought how he could Conjure.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Let your Servant open that door—and draw in the Table as it is furnished by the power of my Art.

sp.speaker: Ian.
sp.p: Ha! was that his Conjuring.—

div.stage: Jane opens the Closset, drawt out the Table.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Wonderfull, a Table plentifully furnish'd! good meat and wine; this is excellent, Wife, Mr. Alderman, fall to.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Eat of the Devil's food!

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: I warrant you 'tis but a Vision, 'twill vanish if you touch it.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: No, though it came by a supernatural means, yet it is no delusion, 'tis good substantial food, such as nature and the bounty of Heaven affords—to encourage you, see I will fall to and eat heartily.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Excellent fare 'faith, wife; fill me some wine; Mr. Alderman my service to you; delicious wine too,—O rare Art; Sir, you are an excellent Caterer.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I could not have believ'd there was such power in Art, if I had not seen't.

sp.speaker: Ian.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, fall to, the meat looks well, and delicately dress'd.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I'll venture.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I'll have it no longer said that the Devil sends Cooks; why a Prince might eat of his dressing.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Pray heaven it digest well.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I warrant you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: A witty Knave, Iane, he resolv'd not to go supperless to bed.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Here, Sir, here's to you, and I thank you for our good cheer.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Your servant, Sir, I'll pledge you a full glass,— Come, Mr. Alderman, my service to you; the Founder's good health.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Auh! what mean you, drink the Devils health?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Will you eat of his meat and not thank him?

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: 'Tis something uncivil I confess,—

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: If you eat with an Extortioner, the money that bought his meat was the price of Orphans tears, and so you may say it came from the Devil too, and yet we eat with him, drink his health, and thank him.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Ay ay, it's not a pin matter, and so Neighbour you are welcome— and, Sir, I thank you for our good supper—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: If you can doe this all the year round, I'll take you to be my Book-keeper —

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: My Art serves me only in time of extremity, when hunger is strong and food absent, and difficult to be otherways attain'd. If done for Covetousness, my Invocations have no strength.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Ah, that's a pity—my Book-keeper's a very honest fellow now I think on't.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: No matter, I'll prefer him—for this you have engag'd me to speak wonderfull things of you—But pray tell me, by what means was all this meat brought hither, and the Table furnish'd; was it by the help of Spirits? I heard no noise.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: It was done by a Familiar that I have command of—if you please I will show him you in humane shape.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Pray do, Sir, that I may thank him.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: O, by no means, Sir,—what, husband, would you thank the Devil?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Why, is't not the proverb, Give the Devil his due? fear not.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I warrant you, Lady, it shall be no harm to you; he is here abouts invisible already.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: It can be no ill Spirit sure—

sp.speaker: Love,
sp.p: Set the door wide open, that his passage may be free.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Quick, Iane.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Mephorbus, that lurkest here, put on humane shape, appear visible to our sight, and come forth in the likeness of a Fine-well-dress'd-gentleman, such as may please this Lady's eye.—Pass by, pay your reverence, and make your exit. Presto, I say. Vade—be gone.

div.stage: Enter Ramble, crosses the Stage, bows and exit.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Iane, step after him, and bid him not go far from the door—you shall call him when my husband is in bed. Go shut the door, Iane, for fear he should return.

sp.speaker: Ian.
sp.p: Lend me your Prayer-book, to keep him off if he should offer to turn upon me.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: So, Madam, how did you like the Familiar?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: It had no frightfull shape—it look'd like a fine gentleman.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I knew a shape that one sees every day, would not affright.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: It was a mannerly Devil too, he bow'd as he pass'd by.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: But pray, why was the door open'd, could he not have vanish'd upwards or downwards, or gone through the Key-hole.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, but then he would have carried away part of your house, for when Spirits appear in humane form and shape, they will be dealt withall as really humane, or else are sullen and malicious; wherefore I bid the door be open'd least he should have bin mischeivous.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I apprehend—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Well, now I'll take my leave—I'll call as I go, and see if the Bride be come yet, and then go home to my wife, poor soul, I shall waken her out of her first sleep.—Well, Mr, Dashwell, good night▪—I thank you, and this Gentleman for my good supper.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Iane, light out—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Mr, Alderman, your servant.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: So, my suspicions were not vain—and my curiosity of stealing down stairs to observe what pass'd to night, has procur'd a good supper, oblig'd the Lady, and diverted the husband; for which I have thanks on all hands, and shall be applauded for a man of parts.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p:
Sir, now I thank you for this kindness, your
Art has obliged me, and you shall find it.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I am glad, Madam, it was in my power to serve you.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Iane, help the Gentleman to a Candle.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Sir, will you please to take that?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Good night, Sir; good night, Madam.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p:
Good repose to you, Sir. [Love. exit.
An admirable fellow this, wife.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Ah fie! a wicked man, to conjure, and to raise a Spirit, was it not a Devil, Husband.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: A kind of Devil, a Familiar;—cou'd you have laid him, Wife?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I have a prayer they say will make evil things flie from one, but I never said it yet, but I'll make use on't to night.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: No come, prethee lets go to bed now, 'tis gone far enough.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I could no more sleep to night without saying my Prayers o'r agen— and I'll be sure to remember that Prayer above all.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Nay, if it be thy fancy, I am sure thou wilt not sleep unless thou dost; I'll go to bed for my part—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I'll say my prayers here below, because I won't disturb you.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: I pray doe, Madam, pray all the Devils out, or I shall be affraid ever to come alone into this Room.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Iane, light your Master up.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: No, give me the Candle—and go lock fast the doors. Good night, Wife.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Good night; I'll come softly to bed, I'll not disturb you.

sp.speaker: Iane,
sp.p: will Mr. Ramble be hereabout?

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: He'll hover near the door, till I give him notice—he begs you to contrive his admittance for one quarter of an hour.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Go you up, and give me notice when your Master is in bed.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Light into the next Room.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Well, here was one defeat of Fortune, but I would tempt her once more and see what luck I cou'd have with my other Mistress, if I cou'd find Roger, and I think here he comes: Roger.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Here, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Have you inquir'd as I gave you directions?

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, Alderman Doodle lives but in the next street, just turn'd the corner there.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: But did you take good notice of the door, cou'd you find it again in the dark?

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Very readily, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Ha! who comes yonder? I discover a pretty face, run you and get directions which is the true door, I'll follow you.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: La la la la la—&c. 'ygad a most pretty creature.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Forsooth, Aunt, this is a most hugeous great place, here be a number of houses, Aunt.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: Ay, Peggy, and fine houses, when you see'em by day-light.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Sha'n't I see'em all to morrow forsooth, Aunt.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: A young Countrey Girle, just come to Town.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: O you can't see all London in a week.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: O Leminy! not in a week, Aunt; and does my Nuncle owe all this Town?

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: All, Peggy, no nor the King, God bless him, not half.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: She appears so simple, young and innocent, and is so pretty, I cannot forbear speaking to her.—By your leave, old Gentlewoman.—

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: How now, Sir, who are you?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: A Gentleman, and one that desires to be acquainted with you and this pretty little Lady here.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: Stand off, come away, child, don't let him be near thee.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Nay, I'll not part with this pretty hand yet.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: Shove him away, Peggy.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: O, but forsooth Aunt, he's a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: Ay, but a London Gentleman; come from him, or he'll bite thee.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Deeds, Sir, will you bite me?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Bite thee! not for a thousand Worlds, yet methinks I cou'd eat thee.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: Stand off, I say, stand off, come away, child, or he'll devour thee.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Believe her not, she's a lying envious old woman; I wou'd hugg thee, kiss thee, give thee Gold and Jewells, make thee a little Queen, if I had thee.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: O dear, Aunt! did you ever hear the like?

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: Believe him not, he's a lying, flattering London varlet.—he'll spirit thee away beyond Sea.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Oh la, Oh la, Oh la! I won't go beyond Sea.—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Thou shalt not, dear creature, be not affraid; good Gentlewoman, do not fright a young innocent thing thus.—I intend her no harm.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Law you there now, Aunt.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: I onely offer my service to wait on you to your Lodgings; say, pretty one, will you give me leave, which way go you?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I don't know, not I.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: No, Sir, pray go about your business, let go her hand, we have not so far home, but we can go with out your help.—get you gone I say or I protest—

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Nay pray, Aunt, don't beat the Gentleman, he does me no hurt, he onely squeezes my hand a little.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Thy Innocence has reach'd my heart.—oh!—

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Indeed I ha'n't done you no harm, not I.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Thou art insensible of the wound thy eyes have made.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Wound! Oh dear, why you don't bleed.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Oh, 'tis in wardly!

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Aunt, I warrant you one of your pins has scratch'd him.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: Break from him, or he'll bewitch thee.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: No no, forsooth Aunt, he's no old Woman.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: No pray don't leave me yet,—I wonder they are not come.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Well, I'll stay a little.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: Yonder comes your Uncle—ods me, he'll knock us all on the head.—Come away, come away.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Hau, let me kiss thy hand first; to part from thee is death.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Hau—what do I see?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Adieu, sweet Innocence.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Men already buzzing about her, how comes this?

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Where there is meat in summer, there will be flies.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: I say, how comes this?

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: A rude Royster here, would stop us in the street whether we would or no.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: O you old Crony

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Don't make my Nuncle angry, Aunt, he did but hold me by the hand.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: How, let a man touch you, O monstrous, monstrous! did not I warn you not to let a man speak to you?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Oh, but he was a Gentleman, and my Aunt told me I must make a Curtesie to Gentle-folks, deeds Nuncle.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Be not so passionate—she could not help it.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: I must seem angry to make her affraid for the future.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: I'll step aside, and watch where they go.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I did not know but it might be the King, they say he is a fine man, Nuncle.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: This was a night-walker, a spy, a thief, a villain, he would have murther'd thee, and eat thee.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Oh grievous! I am glad you came then, Nuncle, he said indeed he could eat me.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: Ay, and so he would if I had not been here—at London they get young folks and bake'em in Pies.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: O sadness!—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: What will this come to? never did I see one so simple.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Here, Link-man, here's six pence for you, put out your link and go your ways—put out your link.

sp.speaker: Link.
sp.p: Yes, Master.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: What made you stay so long?

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: It was so late we could not get a Coach in Southwark, and were forc'd to come on foot.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Oh, Nuncle, we came o'r a bridge where there's a huge Pond.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Peggy, come, give me your hand, Peggy, and come your ways, or we shall have you eaten before we can get you in a doors—here—here— this way—so, so, get you in, get you in.

div.stage: Exeunt, as into Wiseacre's house, he shuts the door

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: A crafty old Fox, he put out the Link that I might not see where they went in—Well, now to find Roger.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Ha, the Light's gone, and I can see no body!—sure 'twas Ramble I saw from the Tavern window—he's upon the scent of some new intreague; if I could have met the Rogue, he should not have scapt from me till he had drunk his bottle—Hark, I hear a door open!— it may be him boulting out of some Cunny-burrough—

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, where are you?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Somebody calls! what can this mean?

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Where are you?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: 'Tis a womans voice.—here—

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Where, give me your hand.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: My Master, Sir, is in bed—and my Lady bid me bring you in—she sits upon the Couch in the dark, she'll have no light in the room for fear my Master should rise, and come down into the yard.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Well, well.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: She desires you would only whisper, for fear of being heard—

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: No, no.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: If any thing happens, step into the same Closset.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: You must not stay long, therefore what you doe, doe quickly.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Let me alone.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Come, Sir, softly.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: So, here's a blind bargain struck up, but there's a woman in the case, and I cannot resist the temptation.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Roger, you are sure you have not mistaken the house?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Sure, ay Sir, I am sure that was Alderman Doodle's house. I ask'd three or four Shopkeepers—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: But are you certain you show'd me the right door?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Ay Sir, there's ne'r a great Door but that. They all told me at the great Door.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Stand there at distance till I step to that house, and if you see me go in, besure you stay here abouts expecting my coming forth.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

div.stage: [Ramble goes and feels out the door and turns back.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: The Door is shut, and all whist.
Will this fusty Alderman ne'r be in bed?
Let me see, are there any Lights above in the windows?
sp.p: No; not a glimps, certainly they cannot be all gone to bed without giving me notice.—Roger, where are you?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Here, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Roger, let it be your care, when I go from you, to buy a Link.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: I doubt 'tis too late, Sir, the Shops are shut.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Give a Linkman six pence for a piece, there's money.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: I see one at yonder Tavern door, I'll step and buy that now, if you please.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Do,—and bring it with you lighted, for I have drop'd a piece of money.

div.stage: Ramble walks about humming a tune, then feels at the door agen.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: The door is fast still, I begin to fear something extraordinary has hapen'd,—to knock is not convenient, to expect is painfull, but a Lover must have patience, a little sufferance sweetens the delight and renders the pleasure of enjoyment more valuable.
sp.l: My trust is still in faithfull Iane,—I hear a noise—
Hark! the door opens, I'll advance.

div.stage: Enter Townly, Eugenia—in the street, embracing. Jane half out, holding the door.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Dear, kind, sweet Creature.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Go, you must not stay me any longer now, 'tis dangerous.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: I heard a man's voice.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: When shall I be thus bless'd agen?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Often, if you be discreet.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Hau!

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: I could live an Age in thy arms, this was so very short

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: E'r long, we'll find whole hours of pleasure.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: But when, when—dear melting beauty—?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Very soon; go, pray go now, I'll send to you in the morning.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Am I jilted then after all—I'll spoil to morrows assignation.— Light here—light.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Ha—who's there!—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Have at the Traytor;—draw, and fight.

div.stage: He draws, and runs at Townly.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Ah, ah, ha—

sp.speaker: Ian.
sp.p: Ah, ah, ha—

div.stage: Run in, and clap the door to.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Master, hold, 'tis Mr. Townly, 'tis Mr. Townly.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Ha, Townly!

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Ramble! What a plague did you mean?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: To have kill'd you, had you not been my very good friend.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Short warning, prethee next time give me leave to make my Will.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: How came you here?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: By the wheel of fortune, I can scarcely tell thee. I guess, I am luckily fallen upon some of thy intreagues; prethee, who was this Wench, with whom I have had so sweet a satisfaction?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I perceive your innocence by your ignorance. Come this way, farther from the house. 'Twas one of my two intreagues. I beat the bush, but thou hast catch'd the bird.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: I only shot flying—I did no great execution—next time she'll be your game.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Curse on all ill luck.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: I told you in the morning, Fortune would jilt you.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: She has in this—But I have another design in store— Come, walk off, and as we go, let me understand a little more of this accident.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: As little as you please at present, for I have Company staying for me at the Tavern.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: I am in haste too.—Come—I find we can make no prosperous voyage in Love.
sp.l: Till Fortune, like the Woman will be kind.
Woman's the Tide, but Fortune is the Wind.

div.head: THE THIRD ACT. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: WHere is he gone, Engine?

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: But into the Garden, Madam.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: I am concern'd at this mistake, which was occasion'd by the Orange wench—she thought I had meant Ramble, when I ask'd her who Townly was—for they are constant Companions, and were then together at the Play.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Such mistakes are often when people are in Company.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Suppose I should tell him 'tis a mistake, and that he is not the person —I—

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: O, Madam, by no means, left for revenge he should discover to your husband—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Do you think he would do so ill a thing?

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: I believe he is a person brave enough, but who knows how he may resent the disappointment; you are to suppose the worst; that would be such an affront—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Nay, I have no aversion to his person, and if I had never seen that Townly, I should have lik'd him extreamly.

sp.speaker: Engine.
sp.p: E'n resolve to go forward now, you'll like him better to morrow morning, I warrant you, you'll not be mistaken in him, he is finely shap'd.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Well, if he press very hard, and I find I cannot come handsomely off—

sp.speaker: Engine.
sp.p: Whist, he's coming, Madam.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: What, Madam, not in bed yet?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Is it late, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Oh very late; sitting up is pernicious to beauty—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: I'll take care of mine from your kind admonition,—I have but little and should preserve it—in order thereunto, Sir, I beg your pardon, and take my leave.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Ay ay, to bed, to bed,—Mrs. Engine, pray help me to a cap or a napkin.—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: What mean you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Faith, to go to bed too.—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: You'll go home first?—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Devil take me if I do.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: What mean you then?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: To stay and sleep with you.—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: With me?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Even so.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Whether I will or no?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: That's e'n as you please; if you are as willing as I, 'tis so much the better.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Sure you are but in jest.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: 'Gad in as good earnest as ever I was in my life.—Come, Madam, act not against your Conscience, I know how matters go; you are a fine, a young, brisk, handsome Lady, and have a dull dronish Husband without a sting, I am a young active fellow fit for imployment, and 'ygad I know your wants, and for once will throw my self upon you, therefore come, Madam, come, your night-dress becomes you so well, and you look so very tempting—I can hardly forbear you a minute longer.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: You are very sharp set—methinks—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Therefore be mercifull to a half famished Lover, and let me fall too without farther ceremony; Dear creature, go to thy bed, and let me not lose a minute of this blessed opportunity, the nights are short.—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Nay I confess, now my Husband is out of Town, I am almost affraid to lie alone.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Truly, and well you may, for I think the house is a little haunted— would I had a bed-fellow too, but the best on't is, I lie but in the next Chamber within.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: If any Spright comes, call to me.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: I thank you, Madam, but if it be not an arrant Devil indeed, I shall make shift to lay him without help.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: I dare swear, she'll make nothing of a Spright, she'll conjure him down I warant you.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Well, well, Mr. Ramble, will you be conjur'd home?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Conjur'd home? no, Madam, the Devil, I am sure, will be on my side, and let me stay here.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: I could chide you severely now, for your ill opinion of me, but you'd not care for't, and to stay longer to give you good Counsell would be loss of time, for I percieve you are past reclaim.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Oh leave not so good a work unfinish'd, keep me with you all night, take a little pains extraordinary, I am not so stiff-neck'd a sinner but I may be mollified e'r morning.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: No, I am very sleepy and must go to bed, therefore pray begone.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: If I go to night, let me be canoniz'd; is't possible, think you, for a man of flesh and bloud, to overcome so sweet a temptation?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Go, Sir, as you hope—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Nay, as for Hope and all that, ne'r question it: I have both Faith, Hope and Charity; Faith to believe you dissemble. Hope that you love me, and Charity enough to supply your wants in your Husband's absence.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I find you intend to be troublesome, I'll leave you.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: But I shan't leave you.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Why, what do you intend to do?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: To follow you.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: To your Chamber.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: To hugg, kiss, and come to bed to you.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: You won't offer it—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Give me a Candle: since you are so resolute, I'll try.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Perhaps you'll shut the door.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: I scorn't: I'll see what you dare doe.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: I'll dare if I die for't.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Take notice then, thou desperate resolute man, that I now go to my chamber, where I'll undress me, go into my bed, and if you dare to follow me, kiss or come to bed to me; if all the strength and passion a provoked woman has, can do't, I'll lay thee breathless and panting, and so maul thee, thou shalt ever after be affraid to look a woman in the face.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Stay and hear me now: Thou shalt no sooner be there but I'll be there; kiss you, hugg you, tumble you, tumble your bed, tumble into your bed, down with you, and as often as I down with you be sure to give you the rising blow, that if at last you do chance to maul me, 'Gad you shan't have much reason to brag in the morning, and so angry, threatning woman get thee gone and doe thy worst.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: And, Sir, doe you your best. Adieu.—
