sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Well here is like to be fearfull doings—here's heavy threatning on both sides.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: I long till the skirmish begins.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: I'll go in and help her to bed, she has nothing but her night-gown to slip off.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Best of all; I'd fain have her at my mercy.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, have no mercy on her, she'll not complain of hard usage, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Go thy ways, bonny Girle.
I had almost forgot my man, I must send him away—Roger, Roger.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Here, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: I shall sit up at Cards here all night but you may go home; get up early in the morning, and come with a chair in sight of the back door— sit in it at a little distance, and wait till I come.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Be sure you fail not to be here early.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: I warrant you, Sir. Well, I suspect what game my Master plays at to night, there will be fine shufling and cutting and dealing—But I am glad I am not to stand sentinell all night, but can go home to bed and sleep in a whole skin—so good night to all and speed the Plough.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Let me see, what has my pains taking brought me in since morning 1—2—3—and 4—Guinies—When should I have got so much honestly in one day?—well this is a profitable profession, and in us that wait on Ladys the scandal is hid under the name of Consident or Woman: I would sooner choose to be some rich Lady's woman than many a poor Lord's Wife. This imployment was formerly stil'd Bawding and Pimping—but our Age is more civiliz'd—and our Language much refin'd —it is now a modish piece of service onely, and said, being complaisant, or doing a friend a kind office. Whore—(oh filthy broad word!) is now prettily call'd Mistress;—Pimp, Friend;—Cuckold-maker, Gallant: thus the terms being civiliz'd the thing becomes more practicable,—what Clowns they were in former Ages.—Hark!—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Where are you here?

div.stage: Eng. runs to the Chamber door and seems to speak as rejoycing.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Ha! my Master—O Lord, Madam, here's my Master, here's my Master, here's my Master▪ my Master's come—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Why are the doors open at this time of night?

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: My Master, Madam, my Master's come, O lemminy, my Master. my Master.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Well, well, are you mad—I say why were the doors left open thus late?

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: I was standing at the door, and my Lady call'd on a suddain.— I am so glad, Sir, you are come home, Sir,—Madam, here's my Master— here's my Master.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Rogues might have come in and have rob'd the house.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: My Mistress has been so wishing all the night you would come —Sir,—Madam, here's my Master.

div.stage: Enter Arabella in Night-gown and Slippers, runs and huggs him about the Neck.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Oh my dear—dear—dear—dear—art thou return'd?

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: I have been come to Town a great while.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Oh my dear—dear—dear—

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Hist.

div.stage: Beckons to Mr. Ram. to slip by—he comes stealing out, Doodle turns and he slips back agen.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: I am so sleepy.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Oh, you are a naughty hubby—you have been a great while in Town, and would not come home to me before—I won't love you now I think on't.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Dear, I'll be going to bed.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Ay, but you shall kiss me first, here 'tis your nown Wife.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Hist, hist.

div.stage: She huggs him agen, Eng. beckons to Ram. to come out and retreats.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Kiss, kiss me heartily—Oh my hubby, dear, dear, dear hubby—

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Hem—em—ah—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: So so, Wife, prethee be quiet—I am so weary, and thou stand'st hugging me—prethee let me go to bed.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Engine, take the Candle and let us go see what's in the house for your Master to eat.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: I have supp'd already, Wife.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: It may be a great while since—come, Engine.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: No, just now—at Mr. Dashwell's.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: And what had my dear for supper—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: A Frigacie, and young Partridge.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: And how far went dear to day?

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: A few Miles—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: And what time came you back?

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Two hours ago—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: And are you all come back together?

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Prethee, Wife, thou stand'st asking me so many questions.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Untie your Masters shoes the while—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: No no, leave your fidling, give me my Cap and Night-gown.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Engine, run into the Chamber and fetch 'em.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: No matter, we'll go in—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Well, Dear, Remember this, you are come home and won't make much of me—
sp.l: I have a Husband, but what of that?
He neither loves me nor my little Cat;
The Cat gets a Mouse and with it does play,
But my Husband ne'r minds me all the long day—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Prethee wife, thou art so troublesome—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.l: There was a Lady lov'd a Swine, hunny quoth she.
Pig-hog wilt thou be mine—Hunh—quoth he—
Husband, you lov'd to see me merry formerly.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.l: Yes, wife, but I am so sleepy to night.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Sir, there's none of your Gown—in the Chamber.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Stay, now I think on't, 'tis in my Counting-house—Go to bed, wife, I'll undress me there, and come to you.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Don't stay to look over any Letters—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: No, no, I'll come presently—

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: So, he's gone—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Fox, Fox, come out of your hole.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I am glad the enemy's drawn off a little—I was damnably affraid of his coming into the Chamber.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: I did all I could that you might slip by—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: I had best make haste out now—lest he return—

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Hark, Madam,—I heard my Master lock the door—and ten to one but he has taken the Key out?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Run and see.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: If he has taken the Key, which way shall I get out.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Ah—ha—ha—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Is all this but a laughing matter?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: I laugh at your faint heart—

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Madam, I look'd down the Stair-case, and saw the Key in my Master's hand, he has carry'd it into his Counting-house—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Nay, then you must abide by't now.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: What shall we doe, Madam?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: You must e'n carry Mr. Ramble, into your Chamber, and let him sleep in your bed—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: What, within there—the Chamber within yours?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Even so, Sir,—and thank your Stars—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: 'Gad, I sweat with the thoughts on't.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: And well you may, Sir,—for my Mistress is given to walk in her sleep—and if in the middle of the night she should chance to come to your bed-side-and take you betwixt sleeping and waking—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Thou hast put a very pleasing fancy in my head—say, Madam, will you be so kind—.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: That may easily be—my Master will soon be asleep, as you may know by his snoring.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: But, should he wake, and miss her—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Must you be the first that starts the question?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: 'Gad, Madam, I beg your pardon—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: To prevent that danger, when my husband snores, Engine, come you to my bed-side—softly, I'll rise, and you shall lye down in my place—

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: So, now I have drawn my self into a premunire—But, Madam, should the Spirit move, and my Master wake and turn to me—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Fool, he'll find thee a Woman, will he not?

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Nay, now I have your leave—and rather than spoil a good intreague, I'll venture.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: An excellent device—

sp.speaker: Engine.
sp.p: Go, get you both in—you, into my Chamber, Sir, and you, Madam, slip into bed, and make as if you were fast asleep—you know my Master's custome, he's no sooner laid than a sleep, and then I'll come softly, and pinch you by the arm to rise—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Rare wench—here will be an intreague.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: 'Tis such an unlucky project, that I would not but venture for ne'r so much—I am pleas'd with the thoughts on't.

sp.speaker: Engine.
sp.p: Go, go, my Master's coming up,—softly—softly—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: And I am pleas'd, to think, when your husband's a snoring, how little he will dream of being a Cuckold—ha ha ha—

sp.speaker: Engine.
sp.p: So, this business is retreiv'd again. I pity their case as it were my own, I hate to be bauk'd in my expectation; and of all things, disappointments in Love matters, are the greatest Curse. Here comes Mr. Alderman, who thinks nothing of all this—.

div.stage: Enter Doodle, in a Cap and Night Gown.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Is my wife in bed?

sp.speaker: Engine.
sp.p: Softly, Sir, she's a sleep.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: So, so, good night, make haste to bed.

sp.speaker: Engine.
sp.p: Go thy ways, Alderman, the Cuckoe sung o'r thy head as thou return'dst to Town to night. Oh the vain imaginations of a husband, who thinks himself secure of a wife, when he's in bed with her!—Oh were I but a wife, what ways would I invent to deceive a husband, and what pleasure I should take in the Roguery!—Well, I long to be marry'd, to show my wit. In the mean time, I am making Experiments at another's cost. But now I'll venture into my Chamber, and watch the Alaram of my Master's Nose; was it ever contriv'd before, that a husband himself should give his wife the Sign to make him a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: My Master, snores already—and I hear my Mistress stirring, now must I to bed, and lye by a dull drowsy Animal; this, or nothing, will bring me to a Consumption.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Hist, hist—Madam—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Here—where are you—

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Here, Madam, give me your hand—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Softly, wench, softly—

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: I warrant you, Madam—he snores like a Turk.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Where is the door—?

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: There, there,—in—in—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Have a care of waking my husband.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p:
Have you a care to make good use of your time, and don't stay too long. Arab. exit.
So—thus far all goes well.—Now must I undergo the severe penance, to lye by a man in vain—and sweating for fear he should wake, and find me out in the Roguery—but I must venture now, let what will happen—So happy go lucky, and to bed gang I.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: without. Fire, fire, fire,

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Hark!

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: without, Fire, fire—fire—

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: O heavens—we are undone—they cry Fire!—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: O, Engine, don't you hear 'em knock, and cry fire!—

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: without. Fire—fire—fire—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: This will certainly waken him anon—Let us cry fire too, and say, I am just got up. Fire—fire—fire—

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: without. Fire—fire—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Get up, husband — or you'll be burnt—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: What must I do now—

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Don't stir out till my Master's gone—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: What's the matter, is the house on fire—

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Don't you hear 'em knock, and cry fire—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Run down, and open the door.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Give me the Key—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: 'Tis below in my Counting house—come down—come down all. Oh, fire—fire—fire—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: What must I do now, venture to be discover'd, or stay here and dye a Martyr to save a Lady's honour? A pox of ill luck still. But here is no smell of burning, nor any smoak, sure the fire is not in this house—But I'll get to the Stair-head for fear, and watch my opportunity to escape unseen—'Tis well I did not undress me—

div.stage: Enter Doodle, Arabella, below in the Street.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Why, here's no fire, nor nothing like it—what could be the meaning of all this Out-cry and Knocking?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: I can't imagine.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: I heard them knock, and cry fire, as if they were mad, and yet when I open'd the door, here was no body!—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: It was a false Alaram—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Where's Engine—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Striking fire within, to light a Candle—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Come, wife—come in agen—this was the roguery of some Drunken fellows in their night froliques.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: I am glad it was no worse—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Ha! who's there—who's there—

div.stage: Going in, meets Ramble coming out.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: A friend, Sir,—a friend—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Oh heavens—Ramble there—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: A friend, Sir—how got you into my house—Engine, bring the Candle.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: I Lodge here, just by, and was going to bed, but hearing the Out-cry of fire, came running over just as your door open'd, and ran in to help you—But I believe 'tis some other house—there's no fire within, as I see—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: I see you are a Gentleman—Sir, your humble Servant, I thank you for your good will, but here's no need of help. All is safe.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: 'Twas doubtless the Roguery of some unlucky Boys. Sir, your Servant, I wish you a good night—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Your Servant, Sir—Come, wife—Engine—lock fast the doors—

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Now you have the Key—open the door agen by and by, and let me in, I'll be here abouts—

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Ah, you could not stay above—you a Lover!

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Dear Mistress Engine, don't chide, but do what I request.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Well, I'll acquaint my Lady—if she'll consent, I'll contrive to get you in agen—

div.stage: Engin. exit. and locks the door.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: And Gold shall be thy reward.
Never was man, certainly, so cross'd in Love—
Surely, some evil charm or spell is upon me.
A false alarm of fire—Curse upon their tongues.
And I to be so unfortunate too, to come down Stairs—

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: The door is shut, and all quiet—oh, here's my Master—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Who's there—

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: 'Tis I, Sir, your man Roger.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: What do you doe here—did not I send you home to bed.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: If I had been in bed, where had you been, Sir—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Why, Sirrah—

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: I'll tell you, Sir—that you may know what a piece of service I have done you, and how fitly qualifi'd I am to be your Servant.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Well, Sir, in what—

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I guess'd, Sir, by your sending me home, that your stay there all night, was to play at a better game than any upon the Cards—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: What, you imagin'd a Woman in the case—

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Troth I did, and 'twas a lucky thought—I was no sooner out of doors, but I met an acquaintance, and as I stood there talking, I perceiv'd a man come ploding a long—go in without knocking, and shut the door— This, thought I, is the Husband.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: So—

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Now thought I, may my Master, be in bed with this man's wife—

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: You had the impudence to think so—

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: My Conscience was so wicked to tell me so at that time, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Proceed.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Now thought I, must my Master be cramb under the bed, or thrust into a Closset, or Woodhole, and remain in Purgatory all night to save a Lady's honour—unless I work his deliverance.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: So, to get the door open'd, and put the people into confusion, I cry'd out Fire—and thunder'd, and knock'd as hard as I could, till I rais'd the house, that you might escape in the hurry—Now, Sir, if you will speak your Conscience, I do believe this piece of policy brought you off— your bare acknowledgment, Sir, will be to me above any reward—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: It was you then, that Knock'd, and cry'd out Fire—

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—at your service.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Lend me that stick in your hand.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: This stick, for what, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Lend it me, I say—

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Here, Sir, here.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Now will I reward your excellent piece of service.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Oh Sir—ô, what do you mean, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: To beat you till you have no invention left.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Oh—ô ô ô, Sir, will you be ungratefull, Sir, will you be ungratefull?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Was it you, you Dog, hinder'd me of the sweetest enjoyment man ever miss'd, just at the very minute I was to have been happy?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Oh 'twas well meant, twas well meant indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Begon and come not near me this week, lest I beat thee to Mummy.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: What a cross Fate is here, I expected reward and applause, but meet with reproches and stripes—but I'll solace my self with the thoughts that the Wise are not always successfull.
sp.l: Fortune's a Jilt and so often doth vary,
That Fools may succeed and Wise men miscarry.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: In two attempts I have been defeated already, enough to dishearten an ordinary Lover, but it was the spight and malice of Fortune, and not want of Love in the fair Arabella, therefore as long as she is willing I will be daring; I am so elivated with the thoughts of her that I cannot sleep, but will spend this night in buffeting with Fortune.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Sir,—Mr. Ramble.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Here have you prevail'd shall I once more—

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: My Lady is willing, she sits up reading and pretends she can't sleep —he is snoring in bed agen—and you have the rarest opportunity— but my Master took the Key agen after I had lock'd the door—and we don't know how to get you in.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Is there no hole nor window to creep in at?

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Just there below, is a Cellar window with a bar out, the shutter on the inside is unpin'd, and will give way, try if you can get in there, if you can, I will go down and show you up.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: I have found it here—even with the ground.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Try if it be wide enough to get through.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: I believe it is.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: I'll come down then and open the Cellar door.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p:
Doe doe—rare—
Eng. goes from the Window. Now for a cleanly conveyance, that I could but pass and re-pass like a Juglers Boy, or were like an egg steep'd in Vineger to be drawn through the compass of a Thumb-ring—now for the Experiment, by this time she is come down on the other side to help me—I'll go heels forward because I don't know how far it is to the bottome—so I am half through —hup—hup—it begins to grow strait—hup—hup—the reward of Lovers had need be sweet for which they endure so much—hup—hup—'tis damnable narrow now, but I'll give 'tother squeeze,—hup—hup—hup— O my guts—I can't get an Inch further—what a spight is this— I must e'n come out agen.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Sir, Sir,—where are you?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Where are you?

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Here, above—the Cook Maid has lock'd the Cellar door and taken out the Key—I can't find it to get down—and if you do get in you can't come up stairs.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: I am half in, but if the door were open, I could not get any farther: I must give o'r for this night, and think of a Stratagem against to morrow, —hup—hup—hup—I am stuck fast—I can neither get quite in nor out.—

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: How, Sir?—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Hup-a—hup-a—hup a—'tis so, I am fast,—there is some damn'd hook or staple on the inside has got hold of my cloaths.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: What will you doe now, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: A Pox of projects—here must I hang like a Monkey by the Loins.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Ha ha ha—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Hist hist, yonder comes company, now shall I be taken for a housebreaker —oh 'tis none but a Link-boy.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.l: Sauny was tall and of noble race
And lov'd me better than any ean,
Have a Light.
But now he ligs by another Lass,
sp.stage: Sings, and as he passes by Ram. knocks his link on his head as by chance and exit.
sp.l: And Sauny will ne'r be my Love again.
Have a Light; will you have a Light?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: A son of a Whore knock'd his Link just in my face.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Ha ha ha—excuse me, Sir, I can't forbear—ha ha ha—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: S'death, how it scalds!

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Hist, Sir, Hist.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Hau! I hear a Casement open above—I fear your laughing has waken'd some of the neighbours—
sp.stage: A Window opens above, and one throws a hamber-pot of water upon his head just as he looks up.
sp.l: It's so dark I can't see—
Oh confound you—

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: What's the matter, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: One Rogue set me on fire with a Link, and another has quench'd me with a stale Chamberpot: faugh how • t stinks.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: That roguish Prentice at the next house does so almost every night.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Never was Lover in such a pickle.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Truly, this is enough to cool any bodys courage: but is't not possible for you to get out?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Hup-a—hup-a—hup-a—all won't doe, I am as fast as if I were wedg'd in.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Be silent, yonder comes some body, I hear 'em tread.

sp.speaker: 1 Ch.
sp.p: Hold, Tom, stay, I am damnably grip'd in my Guts, I must slip a point.

sp.speaker: 2 Ch.
sp.p: Make haste then.

div.stage: Stands with his back just against Ramble's face going to untruss.

sp.speaker: 1 Ch.
sp.p: Oh I am damnably full of wind.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Faugh! out you stinking Cur.

sp.speaker: 1 2 Ch.
sp.p: Who's there, who's there?

sp.speaker: Ram,
sp.p: A Friend.

sp.speaker: 1 Ch.
sp.p: Who are you, what are you?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: A Gentleman.

sp.speaker: 2 Ch.
sp.p: Oh a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Pray help me here, and lend me your hands.

sp.speaker: 2 Ch.
sp.p: What, are you wounded, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: No, no; coming late to my Lodging, and loth to disturb the house with knocking, because of a sick person within; I went to get in at the Cellar widow—and am stuck fast.

sp.speaker: 1 Ch.
sp.p: And can't you get out, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: No, lend me your help to pull me out.

sp.speaker: 2 Ch.
sp.p: Stay, for ought we know you may be some Thief breaking into the house.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: No no, 'tis as I tell you.

sp.speaker: 1 Ch.
sp.p: But how shall we know that?

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: 'Tis true, as he tells you, Friends, help the Gentleman out.

sp.speaker: 2 Ch.
sp.p: Oh, nay then, Mistress, we'll do our best.

sp.speaker: 1 Ch.
sp.p: Hark you, Tom—a rare opportunity—

sp.speaker: 2 Ch.
sp.p: Ay ay, well thought on—but are you sure, Sir, you can't get out?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: No, I have been strugling this half hour.

sp.speaker: 1 Ch.
sp.p: Come, Tom, help the Gentleman, take you hold of him by that arm—hold, Sir, we shall spoil your Hat and Periwig—

sp.speaker: 2 Ch.
sp.p: Give me your sword, Sir, out of your hand—now, Tom—

sp.speaker: 1 Ch.
sp.p: Scoure and away.

div.stage: They take his Hat and Periwig off, clap on one of their old sooty hats on his head and run away—his face is all black'd with them—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Thieves, Thieves, Thieves!

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: What have they done, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: The Rogues instead of helping me, are run away with a new Bever hat, my Periwig and Sword.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Oh the Rascals—Sir, Sir, your crying out has rais'd the Watch, what will you doe now?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Now shall I be lodg'd in the Counter, and carried before a Magistrate to morrow, and all the City will ring of me by noon; I shall be talk'd of in every Coffee-house, and Poor Robin will make me a jest o'r all the Nation.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Give 'em good words, Sir—I'll withdraw—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Hist hist,—I'll be silent, it may be they may pass by and not see me.

sp.speaker: 1. W.
sp.p: Here, this way they cry'd Theives, follow, follow.
Ay, 'twas here abouts—
Ha—here's one lies upon the ground.
Are you kill'd, Sir, speak—?
Ay, if you are dead, pray tell us.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: No friends—I am not much hurt.
Hau, Neighbours, he's half way in at the grates, this is some theif.
Ay, ay, a Rogue, come to rob the house.
Ay, ay, a Rogue, come to rob the house.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Pray help me out friends, and I'll tell you the truth.
Hold there—there may be more Rogues in the house—before we take him out, let us knock, and raise the house.
Ay, knock hard—
Rise—Thieves, here, thieves—thieves in your house—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Now shall I be disgrac'd—
Knock hard, knock hard—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Now, what lye shall I invent to save my credit?
What, don't they hear—let me knock.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Hold—hold—are you mad—what's the matter there-friends?
We have catch'd a Thief creeping in at your Cellar window.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: A Thief!
We believe there are some of his Come-rogues in the house already— let the door be open'd, and we'll search—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Honest watchmen, I thank you—I'll come down to you presently.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Pray, honest Watchmen, help me out, for I am in a great deal of pain.
Come Neighbours, we may venture to pull him out now.
Ay, come—pull you by that arm.—So—pluck, pluck hard—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Oh—
Nay, you must endure't—Come neighbours, away with't, all hands to work.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Zounds, my Guts.
So—'tis done—get up, Sir—
See, the very Iron bars are bent.

div.stage: Enter Doodle, in his Night gown, with Head-piece, and Bandileers, and a Musquet charg'd and cock'd.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Come, where is this thief? where are these Rogues? I'll scoure among 'em.
Here's one we found sticking fast betwixt the Bars in the Cellar grates.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Was he so, was he so, where are the rest?
We suppose there are some in the Cellar, that got in before.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Say you so, say you so, if they be there I'll send 'em out, have amongst you blind Harpers. Oh Neighbours, neighbours, ôh—

div.stage: Doodle stoops down and shoots the Musquet off in the Cellar window, falls backward, as knock'd down, and lets it fall out of's hand.

sp.p: You han't hurt your self, Master, I hope?

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: O Neighbours, I can't tell, pray see, pray see.
No, Sir, I don't see any hurt you have.
You don't bleed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Is my right arm on, is not my shoulder broke in pieces?
Stir your arm, Sir, stir it. Do you feel any pain?

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: No, not at all.
Get up then, Master, there's no hurt done.
Was it the recoil of the Musquet, beat you down?

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Ay, ay, it was always a damn'd obstinate Piece.—Come where is the Rogue? 'twas all long of him, let me talk with him.
Whilst you examine him, we'll search below.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Ay, pray do. Engine, go below with the Watchmen.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: You must perswade 'em to let him go.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: What's the matter here, husband?

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: We have catch'd a Thief, wife, breaking in at the Cellar window.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: My dear, this is the Gentleman that was so kind to come and offer his service to night, when Fire was cry'd out.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Is't so, that cry of fire was his plot, to rob me, but that design failing, he has made this new attempt.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Sir, I am a Gentleman, and one that scorns such base actions— I'll tell in short, Sir, how I came to be fastned in your window.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Ay that, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: When I left you to night, I walk'd down the street for a little air, returning, I was dog'd by two or three Rogues, who came behind me in the dark, and knock'd me down, snatch'd away my Hat, Sword, and Perriwig, and began to riflle my pockets—knowing I had this purse of Gold about me—I slid from 'em upon the ground as far as I could, and strugling with 'em, found my feet in at a Cellar window, and crowded my self as far in as I could to scape from 'em, or at least, to secure my pockets. Finding this, the Rogues let go their hands from my mouth (which till then was stop'd) to pull me out, that they might get at my money—But I cry'd Thieves, which the Watch presently hearing, away ran the Rogues, and so I sav'd my money.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Then you cry'd out Thieves your self?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Yes,—'twas I—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: And have been rob'd of your Hat and Peruque—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Yes—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: How came you so disguis'd, and your face black'd, and that Hat upon your head?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: The Rogues that took mine, clapt this on to muzzle me and stop my breath from calling out—this, and their hands black'd my face so— the Rogues were Chimny-sweepers, or some that went in that disguise to rob—that they might not be suspected for walking about—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: 'Tis very likely husband—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Ay, so 'tis, and if no body be found in my house, I'll release you.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.p: We can find no body, Sir.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: We have look'd so much as in the Oven, and the Cistern.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Well, Sir, your Servant then—Watchmen, see the Gentleman home, and call to morrow, and I'll give you something to drink.
Your Servant, Master.
Your Servant, Master.
What, must he go then?
Ay, he's an honest Gentleman, and has been rob'd himself.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Sir, good night to you, I am sory my misfortunes occasion'd this disturbance.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Hark you, Sir, now the worst is pass'd, let me put in a word before you go. Lord, Sir, that your Mistress was but here in my place to see you now.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: I should not be much sory if she were, I am not the first unfortunate Lover, I'de say it happen'd to me for her sake, coming to see her.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: She could not choose but love you for such a piece of Knight Errantry, and take you about the Neck, and kiss you.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Not till I had wash'd my face, fair Lady.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Oh, don't wash your face, by no means, before you see her, for now you are the Comliest black Gentleman, methinks.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Well, well, Lady, insult o'r my misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: At least, Sir, let your Picture be drawn in this posture, to present to her, and write underneath—The Wandering black-Knight.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Dear, you are too bold with the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: I am glad my afflictions yield any divertisement, another time it may be my turn to laugh, I confess I am a little out of Countenance now.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: What, such a handsome proper Gentleman as you are, out of countenance —? fy, fay, methinks a man of your Complexion should not blush at any thing.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Pray excuse her, Sir,—my Wife's a merry prating wagg—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: I like her ne'r the worse—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Good night Sir—good night neighbours—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Your Servant, Sir,—good night Mrs. Mag-Pye.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Chimny sweep—Boh.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Come wife, you were a little too severe with the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: What, should I have no revenge of him for disturbing us and raising us out of our beds?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen, forward to my Lodging—this way— stay, yonder's some body with a light, I would not be seen—

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Now, you Dog, am not I very merry, this 'tis to be drunk, you Dog.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Sir, don't make a noise, we are near the Watch.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Watch, show 'em me, that I may scower among 'em—I ne'r kill'd a watchman yet.
Who goes there—

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: You are the Son of a Whore—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: 'Tis Townly drunk—
Knock him down—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Be kind to him, 'tis a friend of mine—he's in drink.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Hold—a truce—a friend of thine? who the Devil art thou?
Well, Master, for your sake—

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: For his sake! whats he, a Devil, or one of the Black-guard here upon Earth— No, in my Conscience, 'tis a Jesuite.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: By his Cloth, Sir, it should be Mr. Ramble.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Ramble—what a pox, I should know Ramble from a Black-sheep. Hold up your light—Ramble—what a pox dost thou doe thus like the Prince of Darkness, with these Hell-hounds about thee, and in this pickle?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Misfortunes, Franck, misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Thou art an unseasonable Blockhead, Ned, to go a Masquerading thus, when it has been so long out of fashion.
The Gentleman has been knock'd down, and rob'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Ay neighbours, that comes of Whoring.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Hold your tongue, you'll make a discovery—I confess, I was about the other intreague I told you of.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: And the husband came, and you were forc'd to creep up the Chimny to get away.—This comes of your whoring still.—Hark you Friends, did you not catch this Gentleman Catter-wauling upon the ridge of a house?
No, Sir, stuck fast in a Cellar grates, half in, and half out.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: What, Burglary, Ned, Burglary—worse and worse, this comes of whoring still.
No, Master, 'twas no Burglary—he crawl'd into the grates to save his money, he lost but his Hat, Perriwig and Sword.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p:
This comes of your whoring still.—hereafter, Ned, be rul'd
by me, leave lewd whoring, and fall to honest drinking; you see I am not turn'd Conjurer, nor look like one that had been studying the Black-art. Wine don't disguise a man half so much as whoring, Ned.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Come, prethee go home—Watchmen, forward, this Gentleman and I, lodge in the same house.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Look you, friends, I'll go home if you please, but for this Tartar here, e'n take a lodging for him at some great Inn—hang out his Picture, blow a Trumpet, and show him for Groats a piece. I warrant you, you'll raise a Patrimony,—be wise I say, and get money by him, you'll never have the opportunity of such another Monster.
The Gentleman's dispos'd to be merry with you, Master.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Well; Ned, Fare thee well—to tell the truth, I am a little asham'd of your company at present—I am sory to leave my friend in affliction,—but this comes of whoring, Ned, this comes of your whoring.
What, Master, are you gone?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Hang him, let the Tyrant go—'twill be my turn to insult one of these daies.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: NEver was a more unfortunate adventure▪ the husband unexpectedly to come home when you were going to bed to his wife, a false alarm of fire when she was coming to you, a third defeat by sticking fast in a window, there to be burnt with a link, drown'd with a chamber-pot rob'd of your cloths, taken by the watch, suspected to be a thief, the house alarm'd, the husband see you, your mistress jear you, your friend to come by and laugh at you, in all your afflictions how truly maiest thou sing Fortune my Foe.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: But you were a little too unmercifull considering how my supper fell into your mouth but just before—that the Devil should send you there just in the critical minute.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Right, there was another fine turn of fortune, you started the hare, gave her the long course, I fell in by chance and took her at the half turn.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: I could curse my Stars.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: 'Tis in vain, they will still shed their malicious influence, you will have no luck at intreagues, I always told you so, therefore for the future make your Court to the Bottle, Ned, to the Bottle—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: I would take your counsel and forswear all woman kind, but for the hope I have to bring one of these two designs to perfection yet: my first Mistress err'd by mistake, the second jear'd me to blind her Husband.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Still wilt thou be misled by hopes; hope is yet more flattering far than women, and a greater jilt than Fortune; 'tis the grand bawd to all ill luck.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Her's a Letter, Sir, to be delivered to you with all speed.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Ha—let me see't quickly— Opens it and reads. From Eugenia.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Ay the Devil's coming abroad again to hinder your conversion.

body.p: My Husband will be from home all this morning, I am very desirous to be informed the particulars of last nights misfortune; curiosity forces me, in spight of blushes to give you this invitation.
Enter at the back-door without knocking, if you meet not Jane below come directly up stairs.—

sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Here's another springe laid to catch the Woodcock.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Frank, is not here temptation now, is it to be resisted think you, can flesh and blood forbear going?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Truly here is a very fair appearance.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: What can hinder now?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: The old Devil may dance again.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Franck Townly, give me thy hand—If I fail now, I will, from this time, give over assignation and stratagems and be thy convert for ever—

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Upon those tearms I consent to part with thee, adieu.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Adieu. Now you shall see me return triumphant.

div.head: SCENE II.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Iane, have you sent my Letter?

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, but the Messenger is not return'd.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: It was a very strange accident last night—I cannot but think on't. I would fain know the riddle—I can't imagine how it came about.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Mr. Ramble, when he comes, will inform you all: I look'd out at window, and saw them both go away together—they were old acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I hope the Gentleman, who e're he was, had bravery enough to evade the acknowledgment of what pass'd—

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: I fear Mr. Ramble over-heard too much—and that was the occasion he drew his Sword.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Worst come to the worst—if I cannot cover it with denials, he must acknowledg it but a mistake; and himself in the fault.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Ay, Madam, what made him absent?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p:
Iane, be you about the door below, and watch for the answer or his coming: I do not yet comprehend the meaning of this stranger, [Jane ex.
What made him so curious to spy into secrets of the family the first night of his coming? there is a mystery too in that—here he comes— now I'll dive into that matter.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Madam, good morrow to you, I have watch'd your Husband's going out to get an opportunity to speak with you in private. Nay, blush not, Madam, at any thing that pass'd last night; what knowledge I have gather'd of your secrets, lyes bury'd in this breast, the frolique I play'd last night, was harmless, and for mirth-sake, and such, as I hope you can freely pardon.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I hope you have honour enough to conceal a Womans failings, there was no ill intended by that Gentleman's being there, but your discovery of the person might have prov'd dangerous, and given great cause of suspicion.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I had not proceeded so far, but to clear the house of a Rival.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: What mean you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: By a Rival, I mean an Intruder to your affections, one that invades my right.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I understand you not, Sir.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Eugenia, Marriage has intitled you your Husbands, your duty and obedience are his, but if you have any Love to spare beside, I claim it as my due.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: As your due?—I confess you have plaid the Spy, and know my secrets, therefore may think to make me comply, and to keep me in aw by threatning to discover last nights transactions to my husband, but that is a poor design.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: No, Lady, I scorn that, I have better pretensions and a Nobler claim—Look well on me, though in disguise, do you not know me?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Know you!

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Am I not like one that once lov'd you, and to whom you often kindly said, you could never love any other man? Is Loveday so lost in your remembrance? Have seven years so alter'd me, that I am in nothing, like the man I was?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Loveday! is it you? forgive my excess of wonder; your growth and the small Pox have so alter'd you, that I scarce know you in any thing but your voice, and even that is alter'd too.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: You see, Eugenia, how subject we are to change; but my heart is still the same, and I wish yours were so too.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Be assur'd, Loveday, I can never hate the man I once lov'd so much.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: How young and innocent were we in our first Loves—and all our vowes sincere—but time and absence has effus'd them quite, and your heart has taken new impressions. O, Eugenia, 'tis death to me to see you, and not to see you mine.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Speak not too much, my Loveday, least you agen raise the flame which never was quite extinct, for still it lies hot and glowing at my heart. —But tell me, why came you in this disguise, and with pretence to be a Servant?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: When I return'd from travell, I heard the fatal news of your Marriage, but excuse you, because your friends deceiv'd you, and I was absent.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Alas! they told me you were dead, and I heard it several times confirm'd.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: That was our Parents plot to divide our affections. They writ the same to me of you.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Had I known you were living—

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Well, Eugenia, say no more of that. I come now to play an after-game▪ though you are married, and your person is your husband's, I claim a share in your affections, since wholly I cannot enjoy you, allow me what part you can. I cannot live without your kindness, and since your inclinations to a Gallant, are partly privileg'd by the constraint of your marriage,—I claim that title.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I confess I once lov'd you, nor had my affections ever abated, but from report of your death; the sight of you revives them agen— be you discreet, and I cannot be unkind.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Blessed Eugenia!

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: But why came you in this disguise?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: To get admittance into your house.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: How came you by that letter of Recommendation from my husband's brother?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I took it from a youngman that had been his servant at Hamborough, —He desirous to return to live in England, obtain'd it from his Master, to recommend him to your husband.—Coming in the same Ship together, I learn'd from his discourse he depended on Service, and what provision he had made for his reception here—I receiv'd him into mine, took this Letter from him with design to personate him here, which has succeeded so fortunately, as once more to introduce me to the presence of my dear-long-lov'd Eugenia.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: How shall I recompence this Constancy?

sp.speaker: Love.
Eug.
sp.p: My dear Loveday.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Now the hour is inviting; your husband abroad, no body to observe or restrain our desires.—Say—shall we now? blush not, nor turn thy head into my bosome, but to thy Chamber, my dear.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: You have prevail'd—and I have power to refuse you nothing— retire in there, and expect my coming. I will only give some necessary orders to my Maid, and come to you presently.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: My dear Soul, make haste, for Love has but a short time to reap the harvest of many years.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I must contradict my orders to Iane, least I be surpriz'd by Master Ramble; his coming now is to be avoided as well as my husband's.— O, Iane, what news?

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Madam, Mr. Ramble was gone abroad, but his Man is run to look him, to give him your Letter.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: No matter for his coming now, I have alter'd my mind, I am glad he was not at home.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Will you not see him then, if he comes?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Not now▪—I will tell you my reasons another time.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Well, Madam, 'tis ten to one whether his Man finds him.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Whither are you going?

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Into your Chamber, to make your bed.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: No no, stay, I ll go to bed agen for an hour.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: I'll lay it smooth then for you.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Hold, don't go in, go down, and remain below 'till I call you, but watch my husband's coming, be as diligent to give me notice, as if Mr. Ramble were here.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Yes, Madam. What can the meaning of this be? or is he in her Chamber already, and she would not have me know it—it must be so by her not letting me go in—he slipt up Stairs whilst I was absent—this is but a sudden fit of modesty in her—I shall know all anon.

div.stage: Enter Loveday, and Eugenia—In the Bed-chamber—he unbutton'd, sitting upon the Bed-side.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Come to my armes, dear kind creature, and let me gaze upon thy Charms a while, before thy Curtains are drawn round us, and day is shut from our sight. Thus could I Look, and Kiss, and Hugg, for ever. O! I am in an ecstacy of Joy.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Came you hither to talk, my dear?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: O dear Soul! how kind was that rebuke? come, now to bed— to bed, that we may plunge in Bliss, and dive in the sweet Ocean of Delight.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Some body knocks at the door—who's there?

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.p: Madam, my Master is below, and just coming up to you.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: O, good wench, run down and stop him a little.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: He's coming up Stairs now.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Where shall I hide my self?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Here, in the Maids Chamber, the door's lock'd, and the key out.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Ne'r a Closset in the room?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: No Sir, here, here, cover your self in the bed, I'll draw the Curtains round you.

div.stage: She covers him in the bed, shuts the Curtains, and sits upon a Cushion by the bedside, as reading.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: O, any where.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: So, now for my Book, and a Cushion, and to my devotions—

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, don't go in there, I am just going to make the bed.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Well, I shan't stay—what is your Mistress doing?

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: What she is alwaies doing, Sir, praying I think—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Oh, yonder she is—come wife, pray thee lay by thy book, I did never see the like on thee, thou art alwaies reading one good book or another.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I had just done, husband, and was coming down—that Iane might clean the room. Come, will you go below.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: No, prethee stay a little, wife, I came only to see thee, and tell thee the news—the Bride and Bridegroom are come from Church—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Where were they married—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: They would have no Licence, and so were married at the Minoryes, a place at liberty, because it was more private.—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I would not have been married at one of those ungodly, unsanctified Chapels, methinks, for ne'r so much—'tis very unlucky they say—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: What luck Mr. Alderman will have, I know not; 'tis such a Match, methinks—the Bride is more fit to play with a Barthelomew-Baby than to have a Husband; Cuds-niggs, a Cock Sparrow would be too many for her.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: How you talk, husband—and who was there at the Wedding?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Only his brother Alderman and my self, and an old woman the Bride calls Aunt.—Wife—come hither wife—prethee wife come—

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Madam, won't you please to go down?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Iane, go down, and fetch up your Mistresses Caudle.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Sir, my Mistress has eaten her breakfast already.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Eh—pouh—fetch me a Candle, and my Tobacco box—

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, you won't offer to take Tobacco here, in my Mistresses Chamber.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Hark some-body knock's.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: No, Sir, no—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Eh, pouh, pish—here, here, take the Key of my Countinghouse and fetch the pacquet of Letters that lies in the window.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: You know, Sir, I could never open that scurvy door in my life.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Pox of this dull wench—she has put me by, I shan't have such a mind again this month: well, wife, I'll leave thee, I must go and dine with 'em; I promis'd 'em not to stay, fare thee well, I'll come and see you before night.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: As you please, husband; Iane, go down and stay below.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Yes, Madam,—am I agen sent away, I can see no body— what can the matter be—I shall find it out.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: His absence never was more wish'd—are you not in a sweat, Sir?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I am almost smother'd with the cloaths, I lay so still I durst scarcely breathe; if he had proceeded in his kindness to you, there had been more sacks to th'mill—I should have had a fine time on't.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Ianes coming was very lucky.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Would he not have been put off, think you?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Yes, he's never very troublesome.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Is he quite gone, think you?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Stay, lie still a little, I'll look out at window and see if he be gone forth.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Doe, let all be secure, and then, Eugenia, let us to bed with all the eager haste that ever Lovers made.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Hark, I think I hear him coming up stairs again.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Then, like a Snail, I will draw in my hornes once more—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Shut, shut the Curtain.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, hold, you must not go in.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: You are mistaken, Mrs. Iane.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: My Mistress charg'd me to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: I tell you, you are mistaken; I had a Letter from her, she sent for me—

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: But, Sir, my Master—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Who is that, Iane, Mr. Ramble?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: 'Tis I, Madam, your humble servant—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Leave us, Iane.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: I received your Letter, kiss'd it a thousand times, and made what haste I could to obey your summons.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Things are alter'd since, my husband—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: He's safe, Madam, I saw him go out.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: He will be back again immediately.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: I heard him tell a servant as he went forth, that he should not return till evening.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: He's gone but cross the street, I am sure he will not stay long, let me beg you therefore to shorten your visit.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: You seem to drive me hence, do you repent you sent for me?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: No, Sir, but I was so scar'd last night, that I dare not run too great a hazzard, it imports me, Sir, to be wary.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Well that Conjuring Rascal was a witty fellow; when he first began his frolique, he made me in a sweat with apprehension.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I was in a sad trembling too.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: His calling me forth at last for a Devil, was an excellent piece of service.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I fear'd that would have discover'd all.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p:
I had a Rheum tickled my throat, and if he had not by that
device deliver'd me, my cough would have burst out—I had long before much a doe to smother it.

sp.speaker: Eug.
Ram.
sp.p: What, leave you already, when you sent for me?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: By that you see my kindness, were it convenient—therefore, pray go.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: We have not yet tal • 'd half enough—you have given me no account of the mistake that happen'd after.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: The greatest mistake was in you at the door—there was else no harm in't.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Nay, I ask'd not the question to raise blushes on your Cheeks, they were beautifull enough before, and you may spare 'em; nor can your words inform me much more than I know already, for that person was my intimate friend and acquaintance, and I have sworn him to secresie.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I am apt to believe you thought more than was, and that he spoak more than he ought—this is not a time to come to a right understanding, therefore I beg you would leave me at present—for that young man is still in the house, and should he chance to see you again.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: If he should, I'll bribe him to secresie.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I would not for the world he should see you agen, to know you, lest he should show you to my husband and spoil all commerce for the future, therefore as you hope for future kindness, and respect my quiet, begone.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: I dare refuse you nothing, but methinks so fair an opportunity should not be lost, your husband gone abroad, you undress'd, your bed there, I here—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Iane, Iane, where are you?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Undone, that's my husband's voice, coming up stairs.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: I'll under the bed—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: You can't, its too low.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: I'll into't then.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Hold, no no, my husband's come home to go to bed, he's not well.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: What shall I say?

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Have a care, Sir, have a care—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Draw your Sword, be angry, threaten, swear you'll kill—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Who, your husband?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Any body—no matter—hunt about as if you look'd for some body.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: I say have a care—have a care—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Have a care of what, you silly baggage—? Wife, what makes you tremble—?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: O Lord, husband, I am so frighted—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Hau! a drawn Sword—what's he there—? who are you, Sir? what would you have, Sir—?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Have, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, he is not here—Pray be pacified—

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I'll be the death of him; his blood shall pay for the affront.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, he is not here.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Come, come, down on your knees all of you and confess.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: What means this, wife?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Down on your knees, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Knees, Sir?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: He is not here upon my word, Sir—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: He is not here indeed, Sir—who is't, Wife?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: He must be here, I follow'd him.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, he went out again.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p:
No, he must be here abouts, He counterfeits a rage, throws open the Curtains, pulls off the bedcloaths and discovers Loveday in the bed.
Eugenia soreaks—runs to Ramble, catches hold on his arm and swounds. I'll not leave a corner unsearch'd— Hau—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: A man in my bed.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Oh hold, Sir, for Heavens sake, my Mistress swounds, she'll die away, she's with child, you'll make her miscarry.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Madam, be not frighted, I'll not meddle with him now for your sake.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: What means all this?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Your house shall at present be his Sanctuary, and protect the man that hath done me such Injuries, but when I meet him abroad let him guard well his throat, had he twenty lives he should not live one hour after.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, let me know the meaning of this and how the young man has offended you.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: I cannot think on't without rage, let some of them tell you.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: What have you done to the Gentleman to provoke him?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Done to him, Sir—no great matter—done—a—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I'll tell you, Husband—Jane being in the street and seeing this Gentleman pass by, was so foolish to shriek and cry out, the Devil, the Devil—the Gentleman following her and pressing to know the meaning, the told him that she saw the Devil in his shape last night; and how one in this house rais'd him in his likeness; upon this the Gentleman being incens'd rush'd into the house, ran into every room to look for the young man, and had like to have surpris'd him in his chamber, but fortunately hearing him threaten, slip'd down stairs and ran in here for shelter; and had not Iane and I hid him in my bed he had certainly been murther'd.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Do you not think, Sir, I had reason to be angry?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: What a silly baggage were you?

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p:
Truly, Sir, it was my fright, the Devil last night and this G ••
tleman were so like—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Nay he was very like him, that's the truth on't.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Sir, now you know the reason, I hope you'l excuse my intruding into your house, and I beg your pardon, Madam, for frighting you—as for that Conjurer, let him beware how he stirs over your threshold; he may safer leave his Circle when he's raising the Devil than stir forth of these doors: let him look to't; so your servant, your servant, Oh false, damn'd false woman!

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Iane, go down and lock the door after him; lest he should return and surprise us.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Madam, I thank you; truly, Sir, under Heaven, I think your Lady has sav'd my life, for had it not been for her, he had certainly murther'd me.

sp.speaker: Dash.
Love.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: How happen'd it that you return'd so luckily, Husband?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: By especial providence, I think—I was to have din'd where I told you, but all that's prevented, Mr. Alderman is not like to bed his Bride to night.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: How, is any thing happen'd amiss?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Nothing of harm to either of 'em—But Alderman Doodle brought him news from Change that there is a Ship come up the River, in which they both have very great concerns—I cannot tell you the particulars, but a messenger is come on purpose, from the master of the Ship, to desire 'em to take Boat and go down this Tide—I suppose some seisure of prohibited goods or the like, I did not enquire into the matter—but they must go.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I am glad 'tis no worse—but 'tis some great business that can call him away from his Bride, the first night of his Marriage too—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Nay they are in such haste they can't stay dinner— but that is because of the Tide, I suppose—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: And that is the reason, Husband, you are come back?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Yes, their Wedding dinner is defer'd till their return; and I am glad it fell out so, since my coming sav'd a man's life, for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Indeed so am I, husband, what a sad thing it would have been, if a man had been kil'd in your house.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: No no, it's better as 'tis, come, lets have dinner in good time—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Yes, presently, Husband, Ill go below and give order for't.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Come, Sir, whilst dinner is getting ready you and I will take a turn in the Garden, there we'll talk farther of your concerns, and I'll let you know how I intend to provide for you.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I'll attend you, Sir—I thank you for your generous care. Engenia, now I love thee more than ever—how handsomly she brought all off.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Come, Brother, are you ready to go?

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: I have sent for my wife to speak two or three words with her and I have done.—Methinks it is very unlucky that business should fall out thus on your Wedding day and force you to leave your Bride unbedded.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: 'Tis so at present, but hereafter, I shall never be much concerned at any thing that calls me away, knowing what security I have of my wife in my absence from her simplicity, and I will now show you an example that shall confute all your arguments to the contrary, and convince you of your error.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: I shall not be converted without a Miracle.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: I read a very pretty passage in a waggish book when I was a Prentice, and it has run in my head ever since, and now I will practise it upon my Wife—you shall behold and wonder.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Well, let's see.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Ho, Wife—Peggy—

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: Here, and please you is your Bride— Peggy, where's your Curtesie to your Nuncle and the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: There's my dainty Peggy.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: There is a Gentlewoman without, your Wife, I humbly suppose enquires for you.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Tell her he is about a little private business.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: And that I'll wait on her presently.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Oh fie, wait upon your Wife!—that he'll come presently is enough.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Well that, that I'll come presently.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: And return to us again to take charge of Peggy, for I'll not have her see any London wife, especially no witty wife.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Well, well, Mr. Alderman—come—to my conversion now, make haste or my wife won't stay.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: There 'tis now agen, won't stay—ther's a witty wife for you.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Well, well, pray to the business.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Now pray sit down and observe. Peggy, here, come to me, Peggy.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Yes forsooth.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Your Curtefie—so, that's as I am your Uncle; another now as I am your husband—so, now stand before me—you know, Peggy, you are now my wife.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Yes forsooth, so Naunt tells me.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: And that is a happiness for which you are to thank Heaven, that you have married a discreet sober person.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Yes forsooth.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: One that will keep and preserve you from all the mad roaring Bears, Bulls and Lyons in the Town, that would without him devour thee alive.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Oh, but forsooth, Nuncle-husband, you wont let 'em now, will you?

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: No no, and for this, you are to observe my will and pleasure in all things, and to fear and tremble at offending me.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Yes, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Now tell me, Peggy, do you know what Love is?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Love, it is to give one fine things.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: How know you that, Peggy?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Because, forsooth Nuncle-husband, Naunt said you lov'd me, and therefore that you gave me this Petticoat and Manto, and these Ribbonds and this and this.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Oh very well, she'll learn in time—

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: But now you are my wife, Peggy, and you are to love me, and the love of a wife to her husband, is to doe all things that he desires and commands.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Yes, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: But, beside the Love of a wife, Peggy, there is the duty of a wife, do you know what the duty of a wife is?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Duty, Nuncle, what's that?

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: I have not time to instruct you to night in the whole duty of a wife, because business calls me away—I will therefore onely inform you at present what the duty of a wife is to her huband, at night, which is to watch while he is a sleep, and be his guard whilst he takes his rest.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Yes, forsooth.

div.stage: Enter Arabella Looking in at the door, absconding.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: I have heard all so far, but now I'll venture to peep, and see a little.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: That duty, Peggy, is to be done in this manner; Here, put on this fine guilt cap and seather—so, now take this Lance in your hand—so, now let me see you wal • two or three turns about the Room—so—now this are you to doe most part of the night.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Yes forsooth, Nuncle; Oh dear, Aunt, are not these very pretty things?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: The fool's pleas'd; Oh simplicity!

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: And this respect must you show in my absence; for though I shall not be here present to night, yet upon my Pillow do I here leave my Night-cap, which is the Emblem of me, your Husband; and you must show all duty and reverence to that Night cap, as if it were my self.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Yes forsooth.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: O Ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Can she be so very simple to believe this?

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p:
Peace, let me alone.—And, Peggy, though you may not have been us'd to see this duty of a Wife practis'd in the Country, yet this is the duty of a Wife here in London when their Husbands are absent, and you must doe as they doe here in London.—So now, Wife, let me see you practise this lesson: begin your March—make your low Curtesie to my
Night-cap—so—this likewise must you doe when you leave off at Break of day, as your Aunt will instruct you. And this, Peggy, you'll be sure to doe.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: O in deeds, Nuncle—yes.—

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: So, now help to unharness her.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: I can hardly forbear any longer—.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Well, never was there such a piece of simplicity as this seen before.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Now will she be watching all night, and asleep all the day; so will she be always free from the impertinencies of the world, and I can have no dread upon me in my absence of her misbehaviour.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: 'Tis strange she should be so impos'd on.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: What security like this can such as you have with your witty Wives, who with their gadding abroad, or staring out of Windows and Balconies at home, will draw all the fool-flyes in the Town Buzzing about 'em, till they are blown, and their reputations tainted.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Well, you have your humour—I say no more, but I would fain see the first year of your Marriage over.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Well, now I'll be taking my leave—I commit Peggy to your care—you see what task I have set her for all night: I think I shall return to morrow; but if any thing hinder—every night, whilst I am absent let her doe the same.—

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Keep you the Key of her Chamber—about break of day go in and put her to bed—let her sleep till Noon; then put her to bed in the afternoon agen, and let her sleep till evening. Keep my doors shut all day—and let her remain thus in Ignorance. So fare you all well till I see you agen.—Adieu my Peggy.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Adieu forsooth, Nuncle-husband.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: There's my best Peggy. I wonder now what kind of Caution you give your wife; and what security you'll have of her behaviour in your absence.—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: A little better I hope than you have of your Mistress Ninny there.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Is she here—?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: But I'll give her a lesson shall make her wiser.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Go, withdraw—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: No, pray stay a little, I'll keep the door—Lye there stool—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: What frolick now, Wife?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: You are a going out of Town, Husband?

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Yes, Wife.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Doe your duty then, and come and kiss me—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Ay, with all my heart, wife.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Nay, come not round—but over the stool—nay, jump, jump; come over for the King—here—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: So, there wife.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: So now back agen this way—for the Queen.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: So, thou art such a wagg, wife.

div.stage: She goes round the stool, and be jumps back agen.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p:
There's a husband for you—Look you,
little Gentlewoman, your husband has taught you your duty; now do you teach him his, and make him doe this every night and morning—you must learn your husband to come over and over, agen and agen, and make him glad to jump at a—I'll tell you another—

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: She'll ruine all my design—here—good neighbour take your wife home.—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: You teach your wife to reverence your Night-cap—Look ye, Mistress Peggy, take his greasie Night-cap thus and throw it down Stairs, and him after it.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Away, Peggy, away—this is a Mad-woman—see how she flings about—away, or she will tear thee to pieces.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: O La! Aunt—Aunt!

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: Ay, come away, Peggy—away—

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: So, so; Lock her up in a Room till we are gone.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: So, so, enough, wife, thou had had thy frolick.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: You are a fine man indeed, marry a woman to make a fool of her— you shall learn her more wit, or every wife in the Parish shall be her School-Mistress.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Well, your husband here may doe what he please with you—Let me alone to give my wife what instructions I think fit—I'de fain see what course he'll take with you now.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Why look you, my wife has a good forward wit of her own, and needs but little admonition; but you shall hear now what I say to my wife—Well, dear, I sent for thee to let thee know I am going, and to take my leave of thee.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Thank you, husband.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Now, wife, I need give thee no instructions how to behave your self while I am gone—I trust all to thy own discretion.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: I warrant you, husband, I have wit enough not to doe my self any harm; and for any I doe you, I have wit enough not to let you know it—and there's an old saying, husband, What the eye sees not, the heart grieves not.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Law you there, my wife will have her Jest, you see.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: And this, Brother, you call her waggery.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Ay, ay.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Therefore, husband, as business calls you from me, I think it my right to bid you make haste back agen; for though you carry the Key of your Treasure with you, yet you cannot be secure, since every man has a Key fitted to the same Wards.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Well, wife, I durst trust thee among all the Picklocks in England— and I have only one thing to request of thee.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Only this—That till my return, to all impertinent men, that ask you any questions, or talk to you, answer 'em all with No—Let 'em say what they please, let your answer still be, No, no.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p:
Well, husband, I guess at your meaning; and till I see you agen, I will be sure to Sing no other tune to any manner of man but, No,—
all that I answer or say to 'em, shall be nothing but—No, no, no.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: You promise me?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Yes—sincerely.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: What will you forfeit if you break your word?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: The Locket of Diamonds you promis'd to buy me.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Good bear witness Mr. Alderman—I have done, wife.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: And is this all the surety you take?

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Yes. Arab. And a wiser course than you have taken, I hope, that leave your wife to walk about your Chamber all night in Armour, like an Enchanted Knight upon Fairie-ground.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: I wish he may find it so.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Ay, ay, let us see who'll have reason to complain first—Now, wife, we'll be going to the water-side.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: We must make haste, or we shan't get things ready to go down this tide.—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Wife, you remember your promise?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Then wife, adieu.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Da, da, husband. Well! No is the word. What can be made of this No?
sp.l: Now let a Woman, if Circumstances hit,
Once try without her Tongue to show her Wit.

div.head: THE FIFTH ACT. SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Townly, Ramble, Roger in the Street.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: TO night, Frank, I am for a Bottle, or any thing, with thee; my own ill fortune and thy counsel have at last converted me.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Do you think you shall not relapse?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I have not the least inclination now to any intrigue, except it be with that foolish little innocent thing I told you I met last night; and the thoughts of her are transtory; one bottle will wash 'em from my remembrance.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Now I have hopes of thee.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Henceforth I'll never make Love my business, if I find a Lady willing, and a fair opportunity present; I'll nick the critical minute, go my way and trust providence for such another.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Right, so much I allow.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: This walk in Draper's Garden has done me good.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: 'Twas a fine Evening, but is grown dark on the sudden.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: What women are yonder?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: None that shall divert me from my resolution of going to the Tavern.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: If we had met Mr. Ramble in our Walks, Madam?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: I utterly declare against that unfortunate Gentleman—But if his friend Mr. Townly had come in my way.—

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: You could not have diverted your self now I think on't; you are under an obligation to say nothing but No—▪

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: You should have seen how I'de have mannag'd that No to the best advantage, to the confusion of my husband's stratagem—I hate to be out-witted, and long to try what I could make on't.

sp.speaker: Aunt within.
sp.p: Fire, fire, fire.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Ha, fire! let's begone, I shall never love Fire since last night.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: Fire, fire, fire.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Where? where, Mistress?

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: Alas a day! here, in this house, Fire, fire.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Is not that Mr. Ramble?

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Yes, and the other Townly, the man you wish'd for.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: This is the old Gentlewoman that was with that innocent little creature—I shall find her now.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: Fire, fire.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Have patience, we'll all help you: Come Townly, Roger, here.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: I'll follow you.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: Oh I thank you Gentlemen—Ah, Fire, fire, fire.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: So, let him be for the Fire—I'll be for the Lady—

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Madam, he comes this way.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Run you in of doors, I'll follow you.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Madam, I am your most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Y' Gad but I am, and will if you please.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Will you not give me leave to wait on you?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Nor stand and talk with you a little, dear Rogue?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: I am in love with you; will you be hard-hearted to a man that Loves you?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: By Iove I would kiss thee for that, but that I fear 'twould put you out of humour.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: That was kindly said—there—Now shall I wait on you to your door?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Ah, that spoils all agen—Do carry me to your house—I ll steal in unseen and we'll discourse in private.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Do my little pretty dear Rogue.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Must I then begone and leave you?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: By her answering No to contrarys, I find she has taken a humour to say nothing else, I will fit her with Questions; now Lady answer me at your Peril. Beware you don't tell me a Lye: Are you a Maid?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: She laughs at that.—A Widow then?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: No.—

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: A Wife!—She changes her Note now, and whistles at that to let me know she is, Is your Husband at home?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Is he in Town?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Would you refuse a Bed-fellow in his room to Night if you lik'd the Man?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: If I go home with you, will you thrust me out?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: No.—

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Nor if I come to Bed to you?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: No, no, no, no, no.—Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Y' gad she's run in Laughing, I know not whether she be in Earnest or in Jest. But here's a fair opportunity for a Nights Diversion, we have concluded a Bargain in the Negative already. I'll in after, give her earnest of my Actions to bind her sure for the future—

div.stage: The Scene Draws and discovers her walking in Armour by the Bed-side.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I have searched all the Rooms below and cannot find her,

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: She must be above then unless she be frighted and run away:

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: We'll begin with this Room and search 'em all in order, ha, what Vision is this?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Vision Sir! I am affraid the House is haunted.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: 'Tis she, the very she I look for, pretty dear Creature, will you stay to be Burn'd? the House is on Fire?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Indeed! our House on Fire?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Why, did you not hear 'em cry Fire in the Street just now?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Yes, but they cry a great many things here in London, I heard ' • m cry Oranges and Lemons and a great many things.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Oh! what innocence is here; they had forgot her in the fright and she might have been burnt alive.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: But indeed, Is our House on Fire?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p:
I'll not fright her, I cannot tell, I think—something's—the—matter.
Roger, Run down and see, bring us word how matters go below; pretty Creature what art thou doing at this time of Night?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I am a Wife and't please you.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: A Wife? What of that?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: And this is the Duty of a Wise here in London.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: O Simplicity, what can be the meaning of this? And how long have you been Married pretty Miss?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I was Married this Morning betimes.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: And where is your Husband?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: He is gone a Journey about Business forsooth.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: And when does he return?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I do not know.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
