sp.p: And who dressed you thus prettily?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: My Uncle-Husband shew'd my Aunt to dress me so.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Your Uncle-Husband?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Yes, my Uncle-Husband.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: What is the meaning of that? Now I think on't she call'd the old Man Uncle that took her from me last night, he has Married her, finding her simple they have put some trick on her. And to what end did they dress you thus?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Why, don't you know the Duty of a Wife and live here in London?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Of a Wife! Yes; But what is it say you?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: It is to Watch whilst her Husband Sleeps, and to walk thus by him all Night.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Ridiculous! But your Husband you say is out of Town?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Yes, but there is his Night-cap forsooth, and that's all one.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: She's meerly Impos'd upon, and is this all you know of the Duty of a Wife?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: This is as far as I have learned yet, but Uncle will teach me more when he comes back.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: 'Tis so, this is some trick of the Jealous old Fool that has Married her. Would you not thank a Man pretty Pegg, that would teach you your Lesson perfect before he comes?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Oh! Yes.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Don't you think you could learn as well from me as from him?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Yes, but they told me that such a one as you last night would eat me.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: But no Body shall eat you whilst I am with you, and I will stay with you to night and take pains to instruct you in the whole Duty of a Wife.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Will you indeed?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Lord, Lord, She's willing too, she has more wit than I thought for▪ Yes indeed will I, and now Mrs. Peggy, you must lay by this Lance and these things and go to your Bed.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p:
But my Uncle-Husband said I was not to go to Bed till Morning
that Aunt came to me, and that I was to do so all night, and he will be angry, and Aunt told me God won't Bless me if I anger my Husband.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Never was there such a little Fool as this. But your Uncle Husband came to me and told me he was mistaken, and bid me come to you and teach you the right Duty, and bid me tell you, that you must go to Bed and do as I'de have you.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: O then indeed I'll go to Bed and you'll come and teach me.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Ay! Ay! do dear pretty Peggy, and make hast.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Sir the Fire is quenched, 'twas only a Basket or two that took fire and blaz'd in the Kitchin Chimney and catch'd hold of the Mantle-tree, 'tis all out now.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Where's the old Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: She's seeing the House clear of the People that came in to help.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Steal down then and slip out among the rest, take no notice of any thing, I'll be at home two or three hours hence, or early in the Morning.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Ay, Ay, Sir I'll not disturb you with crying Fire again if you don't.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I must not venture into Bed, the Aunt will be here in the Morning. Let me see, how shall I get out, there's a Bal • cony in the great Room, a little before. Day I'll make my escape there, now I'll bolt the Chamber door and secure my self from a Surprize on that side. Now to my little sweet dear piece of Innocence, that little pretty simple foolish thing. What Pleasure shall I have to teach her her first Love-Lesson. I am almost out of my Senses with Joy. How I will Mouse her and Touse her and Tumble her till Morning, but little dreams the Bride-groom he is to be horning.

sp.speaker: Lovd.
sp.p: Must I be gon then to morrow Morning?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: So my Husband has resolved, he is afraid you should be killed if you stay here in Town, and therefore is writing to a Correspondent of his at Bristol to entertain you, he has provided for your Journey and says you must go very Early.

sp.speaker: Lovd.
sp.p: O unlucky Accident, how he cuts off all my hopes! I cannot think of parting from you.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: What will you do? you must go from hence.

sp.speaker: Lovd.
sp.p: To be defeated after I had wrought my self into his Family, not to gain one hours privacy, one minutes enjoyment of my Love, both to be resolved and willing and yet disappointed! hard Fate, I wish I were now a Conjurer indeed, that could deceive him with a false Creation of your likeness in his Bed, whilst you were in my Arms and I panting on your Bosom. Dear Eugenia, I am almost mad, cannot you now once play the Conjurer for me?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p:
I will try my Art in spight of Fortune, Love shall yet play out the
game, the Cards are now in my hand and I'll deal about once more in hopes of better Fortune.

sp.speaker: Lovd.
sp.p: Kind, dear Woman.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Iane, has your Master almost done his Letter?

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Yes Madam he is coming down.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I hear him, step you into the next Room, listen at the door, but make no noise.—away—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Where, where, is Valentine not come down yet?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Yes Husband, but I have sent him up to Bed again.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: How so, I must give him my Letter that he may be gone early in the Morning.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: But I assure you I think it not convenient you should recommend him to any Friend or entertain him your self. He is not the person you take him for.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: What mean you?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: And has Qualities such as you won't like when I shall give you a farther Account?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Speak plain Wife, what is't you mean?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I Mean, he is a very Impudent Rascal, and only fit to be kick'd out of doors.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: What has he done?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I know not whether he made a false construction of my extraordinary care to hide him in my Bed to day when he was in danger to be kill'd, and Interprets it Kindness and Love to him in a more particular manner. But he had the Impudence er'e now when you were gone to Write your Letter, to tell me that his coming here was for my sake, and that it would break his heart to leave the House till he had accomplished his Design.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Meaning a Design on you?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: A Rogue.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Or that he should be miserable all his life after, and hop'd, that since time allowed him not further Opportunities of Courtship, I would without Ceremony consent to steal out of Bed from you when you were fast asleep, and slipping on my Night-gown, meet him under the Summer-House in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: So, So.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: If, says he, your Husband chance to awake and misses you, say in excuse you were hot and could not sleep, and went down to cool you and dispose you to Rest, or that you went to Prayers.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Very dainty Rogue, was this his Business?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: You never heard a man so confident and so urging, sure Madam, said he, since I have adventured so much for your sake, you will not be so unkind to let me lose my labour and go unrewarded: No, Sir, said I, I will be kinder then so, you shall not go unrewarded, I will meet you as you desire.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: What mean you by that, Wife?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: To be Revenged of him for his Insolence; now that he may not lose his Reward—I would have you dress your self in a Night-gown and Pinners, and go down in the dark, take a good Cudgel in your hand and stay in the Summer-house till he comes, and drub him soundly, then turn him out of doors.—You may let Iane be with you to help you.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I am glad you have discovered the Rogue,—that shall be his punishment; I would not for a 100 l. I had sent him where I intended, an Insolent Dog,—lose his Labour, I'll give him the fruits of his Labour.— Iane.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Get me a couple of good Cudgles quickly, and meet me below in the Garden.—

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Husband you had best have something white about your Head.— Iane, help him to some Pinners and a white hood, and put him on your Night Gown,

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Ay! do so,—here, here,—let me put them on quickly.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: No, no, go down into the Garden and dress your there, that you may be in the way when he comes.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Iane, bring 'em below then. Wife, go you to your Rest, I'll bring you the News as soon as er'e I have met with him,—I'll bauk him for assignations,—a Rogue, Cuckold an Alderman.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Ay do Husband—I'll pray for your good success.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Cuckold an Alderman.—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Iane, Make hast down to him, and when you go out, Spring lock the Garden door that he cannot get in again, and be as long in dressing of him as you can.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Yes, Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Come Sir, come from your Post.

sp.speaker: Lovd.
sp.p: Dear Creature—Witty Rogue.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: How do you like my Invention?

sp.speaker: Lovd.
sp.p: Y'gad you puzz'ld me at first,—when you told him I was not the Person he took me for, I began to—to—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: An hour is our own by this Invention,

sp.speaker: Lovd.
sp.p: Let us retire Eugenia, and make the best use on't we can.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: But do you think how to come off at last?

sp.speaker: Lovd.
sp.p: I'll think of nothing but thee at present, and the Heaven I am going to enjoy.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: But let me tell you, that's a necessary consideration.

sp.speaker: Lovd.
sp.p: Love claims our present thoughts. We'll make those Reflections in our breathing Intervals.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I'll tell it you anon in a word.

sp.speaker: Lovd.
sp.p: Ay ay anon, let it be anon, I am now eager as Racers in view of the Post, methinks I am flying to't.—Now I will plunge in Bliss and be all Rapture, all Extasie, already I am all on Fire, my Soul is in a Blaze, and while we talk I burn in vain.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: And vain is talk when opportunity requires performance.

sp.speaker: Lovd.
sp.p: Come then.—And let our Joyes no Moderation find, Whilst Love has Power, and Beauty can be kind.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: It was very well the Master of the Ship came up as he did, for if our Boat had put off at the beginning of the Tyde, we had mist him and gone down on a Fools Errand, and it would have vexed you to have lost the first nights Lodging with your Bride for a cold Voyage to no purpose.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: I am well pleased it fell out so luckily. Now will I to my little Wife, whom I shall find upon Duty, taking short turns by my Beside.— Well Brother I am mightily pleased with my Invention.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: 'Tis a strange one in my Opinion.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Yes, But a safe one, keep a Woman from sleep at night, and you secure her from Temptation all day, for then she'll be drousie and lying upon the Bed, whilst others are gadding about, and giving occasion, if not seeking 'em themselves.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: I think it a great deal of Cruelty in you so to torment a poor Innocent, I am glad for her sake our Voyage was so luckily prevented, that she may go to Bed and receive better Instructions, what will she say when she finds you have deceived her?

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: I have a salvo for that. I'll tell her that was the Duty of a Wife to a Husband in his absence, and still keep her in Ignorance, that I may have her at a sure Lock, whenever I have an occasion to go a Journey hereafter.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Well! and I will go home to my Wife, and uncharm her Mouth and set her Tongue at Liberty, I can't but think how pleasant a Scene it would have been if any of the Courting Fops of the Times had accidentally met my Wife a Walking and gone to Pick her up, to hear the Fools run on and cry, Madam shall I wait on you? will you accept of my Service? you are very pretty, and a hundred such foolish sayings, and she still answering nothing but No, No, how they'd a been puzl'd and the have laugh'd the while.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Ay Brother—No Body hears yet.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Knock harder.

sp.speaker: Within. Aunt.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: 'Tis I, open the door.

sp.speaker: Within. Aunt.
sp.p: I come Sir, I come.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Now I'll bid you good-night,

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: No, you shall stay and go in with me, and see how obedient my Wife is; and then be Judge how much better my Security is than yours.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: But what pleases you don't please another, I like my own way still.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: Indeed I did not expect you back to night,

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: VVe met with News that prevented our Voyage to Gravesend. But what smell is this about the Door?

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Here's a smell of Soot and burning.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: Alas! after you went the Kitchin Chimney was on Fire. I was frighted out of my Wits, we had the House full of People.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: How, Fire!

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: Thank Providence it was quickly out, it did no great harm, all is safe.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: How do's Peggy, was not she frighted?

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: She poor thing is upon Duty as you directed,—she was close in her Chamber and knew nothing of the Fire; I would not tell her for fear of frighting her, unless I had seen a great deal of danger indeed.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Call her down, let us see her in her new night gears.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: I'll tell her you are come—

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: Come pray walk in a little,

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Well to satisfie you I'll just step in and see her.

div.stage: Enter Ramble above in the Balcony.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: A Pox of ill Luck still say I, this must be the Husband by his hard knocking, that a man cannot lye in quiet for Cuckolds, he has broke the sweetest nights enjoyment. But I am glad I have overcome Fortune so far at last, to get a snap at least to stay my Stomach, though she won't yet allow me a full meal.—I hear some body coming up Stairs.—Which way shall I get down? I must venture to hang by my hands and then drop from the Balcony.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Where have I dropp'd my Glove?— It must be hereabouts. O! 'tis here— ô, ô, ô! Murder, Murder, Thieves, Thieves.—

div.stage: As Ramble is getting down Doodle enters to look for his Glove, Ramb. drops upon him & beats him down.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: You lye Sirrah, hold your Bawling or I'll slit your Gullet.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Auh—ah—ah, He is gone, now if I did lye and he is no Thief then is the business yet worse. He dropp'd from the Balcony, was all unbutton'd, he has been dabling with the Bride,—ay, ay, 'tis so.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: What made you cry out Murder and Thieves? was you set upon? or did you see any Body about my House?

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Returning to look for my Glove,—I did see some body, but I believe I was mistaken, it was no Thief.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Some body that came to relieve your Wife from that odd Duty you put her upon, I believe she is out of her War-like gears by this.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Pray unriddle—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Nay, methink it is no riddle, when a man in the night all unbutton'd shall drop from your Wives Bal-cony and run away.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: How? a man drop from the Balcony?—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Even so; I suppose your knocking at the door allarm'd him, and just as I came forth to look my Glove, he jump'd down upon me, beat me all along and ran away—

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: 'Twas some Rogue that lurk'd in my house, e're since the Fire with design to Rob—and our knocking scar'd him.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Such a thing may be indeed,—but the Rogue was very fine, he look'd more like a thief that would steal away your Honour, rather than your Money.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: Ah! Sir, I fear you will be very angry.

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter, I am not rob'd?

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: No—But Peggy,—

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: What of Peggy—ha—

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: Without my knowledg, and contrary to your orders, was going to Bed.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Now Brother.

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: To Bed, into Bed?

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: Yes, into Bed indeed.

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: Into Bed in Contempt of my Order and Commands, Monstrous!

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Now where's your caution?

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: Nay, I told her you would be very angry,

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: And what said she to that?

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: She said no, you would not be angry; I bid her slip on her night gown and come down to you and acknoledge her fault.

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: Send her down to me quickly.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: She is coming; Being her first offence you may forgive her, and let it be a warning,

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: It shall be no warning to you, I'll turn you out of doors for this, and for such another I'll turn her after you.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Nay, Nay, hear the business before you are so angry.

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: Go call her down to me.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: Yes an't please ye Sir,

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: Leave your ducking and dopping, and tell her quickly.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: She is here an't please you.

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: Go, get you in a while, and stay till I call you; and let me desire that favour of you.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: Yes, Yes.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Ay, Ay, come.

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: Peggy come hither, how durst you neglect your Duty to me your Husband, and go to Bed?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: But I did not neglect my Duty.

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: Went you not to Bed—hau?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Yes, but I went to Bed to learn my Duty.

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: Did not I teach you what you were to do?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: But he taught me a better Duty than that you shewed me a great deal.

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: He, what He? this is some trick, I am abus'd: what he is this?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: He that you sent to be my Master to teach me, that came when the Fire was, and asked me why I walked so, and when I told him you bid me, he said that was but the first Duty, but he'd shew me all the rest, and teach me every nights Duty, and that you had sent him so to do.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: To do how?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Nay but I can't tell you how, but I have learn'd a great deal of him, and if I were in Bed I could shew you.

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: You are a baggage.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Indeed Uncle I had forgot you told me I must call you Husband, and now Uncle-Husband, it was ten times a better Duty than that you taught me.

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: Very pleasant,

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Yes, Yes, so pleasant I could do such duty all night long.

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: Her Simplicity makes me mad; well, and where is this Master? when went this Instructor from you?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I don't know, but after he had taught me my Lesson two or three times;—I fell fast asleep I don't know how, and when I waked with the knocking at the door I could not find him upon the Bed, but I thought I heard some-body in the next Room.

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: Ay, then was he getting open the Balcony; and what kind of Man was he?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: He was such a fine handsome Gentleman methought!

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: Ay, Ay, you only thought so, 'twas all but your thought. There was no fine Genleman, nor no body that taught you anything.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: But there was though—

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: No, no, there was not.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: But indeed, and indeed uncle-Husband there was, now.

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p:
Peace, I tell you there was not? 'twas all but a dream. I spoke
to a Conjurer before I went, to Conjure up something before your eyes on purpose to make you think so, and to Conjure you asleep, and make you dream so, I tell you it was all but a dream, and the Conjurers doing.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Then Uncle-Husband speak to him to Conjure up such a thing every night, and to make me dream always when I am asleep.

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: How she torments me?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Indeed Husband-Uncle it seemed to me just for all the World as if I had been awake,—and I should have thought so if you had not told me what you do.

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: No, No, I tell you 'twas all a Dream; go, go, get you into Bed.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Yes.-But won't the Conjurer Conjure so again?—

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: —No, No, he has taught me now; (a pox of his Instructions;) I'll come and Conjure my self.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: But can you Conjure as well as he did?

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: Never was Innocence in a Woman a Plague before. Yes, Yes, I'll come and Conjure as he did.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Do quickly then, but don't Conjure no fire, I should be frighted at that.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Well, well, there shall be no Fire, go, get you in.— How the VVasp has stung me?—Here, where are you? you may come in.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: I hope she has satisfi'd you?

sp.speaker: Wise.
Aunt.
sp.p: Alas-a-day,—and being frighten'd was the reason I warrant you that she went to Bed?

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Yes, yes, go, go, not a word of any Fire.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: No, no, not for the VVorld; alass-a-day, alass-a-day.

sp.speaker: Dood..
sp.p: Now I hope you see the effect of having a Fool to your VVife?

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: VVell! You may think as you please of the man's jumping from the Balcony, and make false conjectures, but you are mistaken; 'twas only a Rogue that would have Robb'd me.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: You do well to submit with patience to your misfortune, and give it the best construction, since it befell you by your own want of Judgment; I doubt not but you are convinced of your errour though you won't acknowledge it to me.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: By your leave; I am not yet convinced I was in the wrong, and have found no reason yet to change my opinion.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Nay, if your VVives going to Bed, contrary to your Orders, and a man's tumbling out of her Chamber-VVindow are no Arguments; I find you are invincibly stupid, or wilfully resolved to maintain your Error, and so good-night to you.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: The like to you.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: But ere I go Brother Alderman, let me counsel you to go in and teach your Wife a better Lesson, or she'll turn over a new leaf with you, if she have not already—ha, ha, ha—a Wife that's a Fool—ha, ha, ha.—

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Fare you well, fare you well. [Dood. Ex. To have the breeding of a Woman to my own humour, yet no sooner Married but a Cuckold—Nay to have her very flower of Innocence snatched from me, how spitefully has Fortune frustrated my design? But I will resolve to go in and go to Bed to her, dissemble my grief and seem content—though it will be a sharp corrosive to my mind..., ha! here comes a Gentleman, It may be my Wife's Instructor—I'll stand by and observe if he hanckers about my House or leers up at the Window, that I may know him another time.

sp.speaker: Townley.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha—No, no, no, Hau! what's here?

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Who is that Mr. Townley?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: The same Sir. Is it you Mr. Alderman Wiseakers?

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Yes Sir—you are in a merry humour, where are you going so late?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: I was going to the Tavern to a Friend to tell him the pleasantest adventure I ever met with.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: This may be concerning my Wife— [Aside. Pray what was it Sir? if it be no secret, sure it was very pleasant you are so merry after it.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Going along the Street to night, it was my Fortune to offer my Service to a Lady.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Ay, ay, a handsome Lady cannot escape you Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Handsome or not I don't know, for she was muffled up in her hoods, and I could not see her face. But I have had three or four hours of the sweetest enjoyment Man ever had with Woman.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: That was pleasant indeed Sir—This was the Man.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: This Lady had taken up an odd humour to say nothing but no, no.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: No Sir, hau!—

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Yes Sir, to what ever I said she would answer nothing but No,— not a Word could I get from her but No, no, no.—

sp.speaker: Wise,
sp.p: Hau Brother Alderman—this was his Wife. Now will I go and stop his mouth,—he will be prating else on't: do you know who this Lady was Sir.—

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: —Not I.—

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: —Nor you don't know her again if you should meet her?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: —Not I.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: —A Witty Woman y'faith,—Are you obliged Sir to go to the Tavern you were speaking of?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: —Why do you ask?

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: Because I have a great Curiosity to hear this Story at large, and if you are not engaged, I would desire your good Company at a Neighbours house where I am going to drink a glass of Wine, and as we go you may tell it me with all the circumstances,—it must needs be very pleasant, and worth hearing.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: —Well Sir, I'll wait on you, and as we go you shall hear it all.

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: Come Sir, 'tis but just by here.

div.stage: Enter Doodle, Arabella, and Engine, in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Wise, I am glad to find you up, But am sorry thou art in pain.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: I was so extremely troubled with the Tooth-ach that I could not sleep, and therefore got up to take a walk here in the Garden, thinking I might rest better afterwards—.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Come Wife, a glass of Sack will do thee no harm, I must drink a glass or two before I go to Bed, to take the rawness off my Stomach— and 'twill do thy Teeth good too—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Nay the pain is pretty well abated now.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Come let us sit down in the Arbour then—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Mrs. Engin, Run up and smooth the Bed, and lay the Pillows to rights.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Yes, Yes—.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Arabella, here's to thee—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Thank you Husband—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: If I had happen'd to have stay'd a Week away, how wouldst thou have long'd to have had thy Tongue at Liberty?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: No, I should have done well enough.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: But Silence is very burdensome to a Woman.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: I confess the Tongue is our unruly Member,—but you had no security in that, if I had had a mind to do you know what,—Silence you know gives Consent.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: But if any of the fluttering Sparks had come buzzing about thee, thy Tongue wou'd have so itched to have been at them, I have known thee so smart upon 'em at the Plays—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Oh! I never do that but when you are there to defend me, for sometimes they'l be Rude and Abuse a Woman if they see her alone.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: O, rare Sparks of Chivalry, when they have not wit enough to talk to a Woman, have Courage enough to beat her and tear her Hood and Scarf.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Husband here's to you, you are welcome home—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Hark, somebody knocks,—who can it be at this time of night?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Pray Heaven my Spark han't found the way back again—

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: So when she led you out blindfolded she gave you the slip?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Cunning Baggage.

sp.speaker: Engine.
sp.p: Here is Mr. Alderman Wiseakers come to see you.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: And Townly with him—what can the meaning be of his coming again, and with him?—

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Just as you parted from me—something came in my head that I had a mind to speak to you about,—and meeting this Gentleman of my acquaintance, I brought him along with me to drink a glass of your Wine, Mr. Alderman.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: The Gentleman is welcome, I just call'd for a Bottle. Sir my Service to you—

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Your Servant Sir.—Madam my humble Service to you—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Your Servant.—I am in amaze!

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Now pray tell me what business brought you to—

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Pray ask Qu • stions anon,—and have patience to hear one of the pleasantest Stories from this Gentleman that ever you heard: Sir will you do me the favour but to tell that Story again?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: With all my heart Sir.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Sure he has not told him what pass'd, I am mistaken if he could know me again.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Come Sir begin.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Going along the Street this Evening when it was dark, it was my Fortune to meet with a Lady, to whom I began to make some little Courtships, but to everything I said, she answered nothing but No.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Ha—!

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Nothing but No still? what er'e I ask'd her was no.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Hum—so Sir.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: I asked her if I should be her Servant, she said no, if she would let me wait on her home, she said no, no still. At last perceiving she was resolved to make no other Answer: I studied to ask such questions, and say such things to her that if she answered no, it would please me well.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Very good Sir;

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: I shall be discovered—what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Pray mind Sister.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Ay, I do, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: —Well Sir, and how then?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: —I asked her then if she would not be angry if I went home wit her, she said no.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: No, Brother.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: If she would not shut the door against me?—No.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: No, said she again.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: If she would Lye alone to night—she said no.—

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: If she would be angry if I came to Bed to her? no—

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: No, no, she said no, Brother.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Well, well, I observe—Humh—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: I shall be undone if he goes forward.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Pray sit still Sister, and mind this Story out.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Ay, I do—

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Well Sir go on, you'll hear anon Brother.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Yes, pray go on.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: So Sir.

div.stage: Arabella drinks, and whilst Townly and she both offer to fill the Glass, she drops a Ruby Ring into the Glass—Townly takes the Glass, and talks o're it.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Sir my Service to you first.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Pray Madam give me leave to fill.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Excuse me Sir, you shan't indeed.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: your Servant Madam. So I'll tell you Gentlemen, upon this I saluted the Lady, and being now just come to her very Door—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Pray drink Sir.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: By and by Sister, pray let him go on.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: In ran she,—in ran I, up Stairs went she—up went I after her,—she into her Chamber,—I followed her,—she locks the door,—very glad was I,—throws her self upon her Bed,—down throws I my self by her,—or upon her as you may guess.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: What shall I do!

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: And not a word but no, said the Lady all this while, no, was the word Brother.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Ay, Yes, yes,—I observe,—I observe.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Come Sir, pray begin this Lady's good health, you can't but drink her Health for her Kindness, that's the least you can do.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Madam, I'll drink it as long as I live for her sake.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Come then, pray begin it to me.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: With all my heart Madam.

sp.speaker: Wis.
sp.p: Lord Sister you are so full of Interruptions! can't you let the Gentleman go on with his story?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: I thought there had been an end when he was got to Bed to her.

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: —No, no, there's more yet.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Well, but the Gentleman may drink first, the Wine will die.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Then Madam my Service to you, here's a health to the Negative Lady.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Off with it every drop in honour of the Lady—

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Ha, a Ring in my mouth,—and the Ring—Mum—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Come I'll pledge the Lady No's health.—

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Well, to make my Story short—

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: Ay Sir, the rest of the Story—

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: I had the happiness to tumble this Lady's Bed some hours, behav'd my self like a Man,—found her brisk and active, but on a sudden she rises from me, plucks me by the elbow to get up, then blind, me with her handkerchief, leads me out of doors a good way from her house, gives me a turn round, and slips away from me;—when I perceiv'd her gone, I pluck'd off her handkerchief, thinking to see where she went in, that I might be so happy to find this kind person another time,—and turning back methought I had a glimps of her, but running after her stumbled against a great Stone, fell down, and so lost sight of her.—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Then you did not see where she went in?—

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: No, for with the fall I wak'd out of my Dream.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Why then all this is but a Dream.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: How! a Dream.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Ay Sir, a Dream.

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: VVhy you did not tell me it was a Dream.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: No Sir, that may be, for we arrived here just as we came to that part of the story, which prevented me from telling you how I awak'd.

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: You told me you came then from the Lady, and was going home to your Lodging.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Yes Sir, For when I waken'd, I was so pleased with my Dream, and so possessed with the Fancy, that immediately I got up and went to the place where I dream'd I fell, to see if there was any such stone as I tumbled at, and if I found such a stone, to look if there were any such House thereabouts as methoughts I saw her slip into just as I fell.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: And found you any such stone, Sir?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Yes, I found just such a stone.

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: But would a Man rise out of his Bed for this?—

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: I have great Faith in Dreams.—

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: By your leave Sir, you told me that you put a Ring upon the Ladys Finger when you were upon the Bed with her.—

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: I did so; now it work'd strongly in my Fancy, that if I went abroad and could find any such stone, or a house like that, some good luck or other would befall me thereabouts.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: And pray did any thing extraordinary happen?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Yes, looking for the Stone I found this Ring, and tis exactly such a Ring as I dream'd I put upon the Ladies Finger.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: This is wonderful.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Stranger things than this have happen'd to me upon account of Dreams.—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Now Sir, I'll tell you, there's more in this than you are aware of.— —I was this night to have gone to Gravesend,—and as I was taking leave of my Wife, a Frolique took me in the head to make her promise that if any Gentleman should talk to her during my absence, or ask her any questions, she should to all they said answer nothing but No, and there's your Dream out.—

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: How Sir! Is this true?—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Ay indeed Sir, here's my Wife, and here's Mr. Alderman too can witness the same

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: I will assure you Sir, this is true.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Ay Sir, it is true.—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: He has brought all clear off.—

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Well Sir, if the Person that answered me was your Wife here, I must beg your Pardon if I have made you a Cuckold.—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: How Sir I pray?—

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: 'Twas in a Dream Sir, but so sweet a Dream, I could wish to Dream't a thousand times or'e, O Madam! are you my Lady No?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Truly Sir, knowing what my Husband has told you of my Promise: I much wondred all the while where the Story would end,—I perceived he was uneasie, and I was as much surprized.—It was so pat to our purpose.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Truly Wife I could not tell what to think on't, till I heard it was but a Dream.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Well Mr. Alderman. I thank you for bringing me to the sight of the Lady I dream'd of, whose Face was the only thing in the World I desired to see.—I can't almost fancy but that I am in a Dream still; methinks this looks more like a Dream than the other,

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Ay ay Sir, this is more like a Dream behalf.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Have a care Sir the next time you have a fair Lady in view, you make no such stumbles to lose sight of her, that you may know where to find her without shewing.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: And let Ladies have a care of leading me forth to Blind-man's Buff.—

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: And I say let Husbands have a better stratagem hereafter to secure their Wives, than learning them to say nothing but No.—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: You think then there is more in this than a Dream?—

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Yes, and I brought this Gentleman on purpose to let you see what is become of your No; there's a fine business indeed, No.—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Hark you Brother Alderman,—carry him home to your own house, and let him see what's be • ome of the Lady upon Duty,—and the Gentleman that dropp'd down from the Balcony;—and what becomes of your No, then?

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: You know not what you say, you are in a Dream; ha, ha, ha.—

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: And I think your Wife w • s in a fine Dream.— What think you of a fool for a Wife now?—

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: As well as of a No witty Wife. ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: What's the meaning of all this Madam?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: —They don't know themselves.

div.stage: Dashwel and Jane upon a Mount, looking over a Wall that parts the two Gardens.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Speak to 'em Sir, or their noise will spoil your design.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Hark you Mr. Alderman, and Mr. Alderman there.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Heaven! What foul Fiend is that?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Neighbour Dashwell!

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Turn'd Cotquean!

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: What means this?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p:
You'll see anon. But pray in the interim leave your disputes of a witty Wife or a foolish Wife: and learn by an example presently, that
you are both in the wrong, as I told you before; and now be convinced what 'tis to have a zealous Wife.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Why I pray what has't to say as to that matter?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: A Villain has tempted my Wife to meet him in the Garden, here at this Summer-house when I am in Bed; to commit his Fellonious purpose against my Honour. ... She has proved her self a Virtuous, good Woman, and acquainted me with the wicked Machinations, and has advised me to dress my self up thus, and to give him entertainment here in the dark in her room, and see how I am prepared to welcome him.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Hark Sir? the Garden door unlocks. The Traitor is coming.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Hist! then be silent all I pray. Put out your Candle, and go softly to the dore there that opens out of your Garden into mine. I have unbolted it on this side: VVhen you hear a noise, come in, but do not help the Rogue though hecry out never so: For I will so Caresse him.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: No, no, lay him on—

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Lay him on soundly.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Come follow me, and I'll lead you all to the dore.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Now if all this should be Artifice betwixt the Wife and her Gallant?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Follow, follow. VVe shall be able to guess anon.

div.stage: Enter Loveday in the Garden with a Hunting Whip in his hand. Dashwel and Jane at a Distance.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Iane, I hear him come—Stand close, be ready.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: I warrant you Sir.

sp.speaker: Lovd.
sp.p:
Oh that Heaven of Beauty I have lest, that the sweet enjoyment might have for Ages lasted! I'd be content to give a Year of coming
〈◊〉 for every hour of Bliss. But I must a while respite the memory of that happiness; and employ my thoughts how to come off with the Husband, for that is my present Task.

sp.speaker: Dash,
sp.p: Hem. Hem.

sp.speaker: Lovd.
sp.p: The Cuckold Hems! Little thinks he how he is counter-plotted; hist where are you?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Hem, Here.

sp.speaker: Lovd.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Hist Here, here; hist.

sp.speaker: Lovd.
sp.p: Oh my Dear! art thou here? Let me prepare my Arms to embrace thee, and give thee the sweet enjoyment of my Love! receive it then in this kind, hearty Salutation.—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Hold, hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Lovd.
sp.p: I'll take down your Courage.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Hold, help, help.

sp.speaker: Lovd.
sp.p: Make appointments in the dark!

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Wrong my Lady.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: They swinge him bravely.

sp.speaker: VVise,
sp.p: That we cou'd but see now!

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Yonder comes a Light.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Oh! Murder! Murder! Murder. Oh! oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Lovd.
sp.p: D • d you think it cou'd be my intention ever to wrong so worthy a Gentleman as your Husband?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Oh! hold, hold, y'are deceived—

sp.speaker: Lovd.
Dash.
sp.p: Here, here, bring the Candle; I say you are deceived.—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Well Husband, have you met with him handsomely?—

sp.speaker: Lovd.
sp.p: Ha! Madam Eugenia; who have I been handling then all this while?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Oh Wife! I have been lash'd and beat here most unmercifully.

sp.speaker: Lovd.
sp.p: O Lord Sir! Is it you?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: How! have you been beaten? Sirrah, I'll have you hang'd; first tempt me, and then beat my Husband.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Nay, nay, Wife—'twas a mistake.

sp.speaker: Lovd.
sp.p: Oh misfortune! have I been injuring you Sir, all this while?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Nay, Nay; I am convinc'd it was well meant.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I acquainted my Husband with your Intentions, and sent him in my place to be revenged of you for your Insolence.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Mr. Dashwell, you have paid him off; ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Indeed Neighbour you have cool'd his Courage for him: Do not your Arms ake? ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Well, well; talk no more of it, he did it but to try my Wife for my sake; he meant no hurt.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: I find how the Cards have been dealt.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Hark you Neighbour Dashwell; Now if your Zealous Wife should have put a Pious Cheat upon you?

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: 'Tis very suspicious: What should make him a Stranger so zealous to try your Wife for you?

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: I am affraid he has try'd her for you-Neighbour.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Well, well, censure as you please: But this misfortune is a great satisfaction to me; I heard your Story e'ne now in the Garden, and I would not yet change my VVife for her that a man leapt from her VVindow, nor for the Lady No, of whom that Gentleman Dream'd such a fine Dream there; ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: Come friend, bring him along.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: How? Ramble here?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: My unlucky Lover!

sp.speaker: VVatch.
sp.p: An't please you Mr. Alderman there was a cry of Thieves at your door, as we were coming from the Stand to you, we met this Gentleman here, running along in a very suspitious manner.

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: It was Mr. Alderman Doodle there that cry'd out Thieves; but it was a mistake; you may let the Gentleman go,

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: But I dare take it upon my corporal Oath this is the Gentleman that leapt down from the Balcony.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Oh pray now shew him me quickly, pray now!

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Look you, they are all here.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Oh Uncle Husband!

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: What come you for?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Indeeds Husband Uncle my Aunt told me this Gentleman was carried away for a Thief, and that he had robb'd you, and must be hang'd.

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: And how then?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: And so I come to tell you he stole nothing that I saw. He did nothing but teach me the Duty of a Wife, did you Sir?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: No, no, pretty one.

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: Go, go, you are in a dream still.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Oh but it was no dream though! Now I see the Gentleman, I am sure he taught me my Lesson.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha. There's Simplicity for you Brother.

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: Take her hence.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Deeds Nuncle Husband I had not come here but for sake o'the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: Take her away or I'll break your bones.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: Ah woe is me! we shall be all hang'd, all hang'd.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Mr. Alderman, much good d'ye with your Foolish Innocent Wife.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Pray Sir what think you? is she so very Innocent?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Faith Madam I think she has good Natural Parts.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: But for a Woman to kiss and tell; Oh la!

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Now Mr. Alderman you see the effects of having a silly Wife: And now I hope at last you are convinced?

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: No, no, ne're a whit, and so pray concern you your self with you zealous Wife there, who was above at her Devotions. And when the zealou fit was over, sent that Gentleman there to chastise you in the Garden for your folly.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Well, well, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: And you Brother Alderman, concern your self with your no, Stratagem, and your no, witty Wife—for she has done No—thing. And you are No—Cuckold; good night to you.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: VVise.
sp.p: Hence-forth I'll keep her under Lock and Key, and n'er more trust a Wifes simplicity.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Sir, I find you are the Charitable man that has instructed the Ignorant.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Yes, yes, he has taught her more Wit.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Now Sir; give me leave to make peace with you for this friend of mine, and forgive him his Conjuring.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: How! Valentine Loveday my Friend; were you the Conjurer then? How long have you been come from Hamborough?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: How! Valentine Loveday, and from Hamborough!

sp.speaker: Lovd.
sp.p: I am discovered.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: My Wives former Servant, nay then I fear there's something more in this business than I yet apprehend.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: You have made Mischief, Ned.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Pray Sir how came you to use this trick to get into my Service? I wondred at my Brother to send Letters.

sp.speaker: Lovd.
sp.p: How I came by his Letters I'll acquaint you hereafter. Some Friends of mine at Hamborough, who went lately from England told me since she was Married to you, she had forfeited my good Opinion, and lost her virtuous inclinations—as they supposed, disgusted with her Marriage.

The truth of this I resolved to know, purposing never to Marry, nor put trust in woman-kind if she was false; But now I am assured of her Vertue, I will pursue my intentions of coming over, and Marry with speed.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: He has a quick invention.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I am neither beholden to them for their Opinion, nor you for your Belief.

sp.speaker: Lovd.
sp.p: And now Sir I hope you are satisfied, and give me your pardon

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Ay! Yes, but not so well satisfied neither.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Mr. Dashwel; you may well scratch your Head, for all your Wives Vertue you'll see the fruits of her Zeal upon your fore-head ere long.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I would not yet change my Wives Vertue for your Wives Wit, Mr. Alderman.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: But Neighbour I think, Consideratis Considerandis, the Witty Wife is yet the best of the Three.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: To that I answer in your Wives own Dialect; No.

sp.speaker: Dood.
sp.p: VVell, well, go in and noint your back Neighbour, you have been finely slaugh'd, ha, ha, ha; Sir you are an excellent Flaugher, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: How our Cuckolds laugh at one another?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Now I find how I lost both my Mistresses; Eugenia repulsed me for you, Loveday, and you Townly leap'd into that Lady's Saddle before me.— But I am sure of my pretty Fool when ere I can come at her.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Eugenia I now spy the Hypocrite under the Veil of Devotion. I always had too good an opinion of your wit, to believe you were in Earnest; now we know one another better, let us meet to morrow; Each confess the whole truth, and laugh heartily at the folly of our Husbands.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: With mine you see how smoothly matters went, He is a Cuckold, Cudgell'd, and Content.

sp.speaker: Ramble.
sp.l: ROuze up ye drouzie Cuckolds of our Isle,
We see your aking hearts through your forc'd smile.
Haste hence like Bees, unto your City Hives,
And drive away the Hornets from your Wives.
Rouze, Rouze I say as do the Nobler Deer;
In Parks, when they the noise of Hunters hear,
Ioyn in a herd for their defence, and there
Erect their large Brow-Antlers in the Air.
A vision like to that methinks i'th' Pit
I see, and every Cuckold is a Cit.
But what provok'd the Poet to this Fury,
Perhaps he's piqu'd at by the Ignoramus Iury,
And therefore thus Arraigns the noble City,
No, There are many Honest Loyal Witty,
And be it spoke to their eternal Glory's,
There's not one Cuckold amongst all the Tory's.
Yet still he'l rail, and all the world will blame us,
'Till Billa Vera conquers Ignoramus;
'Till you, the Bully's of a Common-wealth,
Leave breaking Windows for a Loyal Health.
No, no, the Cloven Foreheads are the Whigs, who send
Their Wives a Bulling to their Morefields friend.
The Doctrine put into 'em do's so tickle
They'r pleas'd with nothing like a Conventicle.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dashwell.
sp.l: In me the effects of zealous Wives you see,
What say the London Wiseakers to me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dashwell.
sp.l: You Wives of the last zealous Reformation
On Husbands Foreheads to your Reputation,
Do fix the Mark of their Predestination.
Your zeal's all counterfeit and nothing worth,
Although you have such able Holders-forth.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Doodle.
sp.l: What say you friends unto a Wife that's Witty?
Have you such Wives as I am in the City?

sp.speaker: Ald. Doodle.
sp.l: Yes, yes by my troth; but the more's the pity.
They'l never be content with our dull sport
So long as Tory's visit 'em from Court.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.l: Wise'akers. Take warning too by me (dear City Friends)
A wife like mine will make ye all amends,
A pox upon't! mine was a Country Cheat;
The sillyest of 'em all find out that Feat.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: Wise'akers. Yes, yes let him that does desire a Fool
To's Wife, make hast and send her here to School.
